data.name: Introduction
entries: Dungeons & Dragons is a cooperative game in which players create exciting fantasy stories guided by a Dungeon Master, or DM. Imagination and chance determine the fate of the players' characters.

entries.name: An Ongoing Game
entries: Each time you gather to play D&D, you're playing a single game session. These sessions connect to form adventures like the one in this set. The next time you play, the story picks up where you left off.

entries.name: Choose Your Role
entries: To play D&D with these adventures, you need two to four people to play as characters and one person to be the Dungeon Master, or DM.

entries.name: Playing a Character
entries: If you want to be one of the protagonists in your group's adventures, consider playing a character. Here's what these players do:

items.name: Make a Character
items.entry: Your character is your alter ego in the fantasy world of the game. Make a level 1 character using the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}. The adventures in Heroes of the Borderlands were designed with the Cleric, Fighter, Rogue, and Wizard classes in mind, but any class will do.

items.name: Team Up
items.entry: Your character joins the other players' characters to form an adventuring party. These adventurers are allies who face challenges and fantastical situations together. Each character has distinctive capabilities that complement those of the other characters.

items.name: Venture Forth
items.entry: Your character's group explores locations and events presented by the DM. You can respond to them however you can imagine, guided by the rules. Although the DM controls all the monsters you encounter, the DM isn't your adversary. The DM guides your party's journey as your characters become more powerful.

entries.name: Being the Dungeon Master
entries: If you want to be the mastermind of the game, consider being the DM. Here's what DMs do:

items.name: Run the Adventure
items.entry: You run the adventures within.

items.name: Guide the Story
items.entry: You narrate much of the action during play, describing locations and creatures that the adventurers face with read-aloud text. The players decide what their characters do as they navigate hazards and choose what to explore. Then you use a combination of imagination and the game's rules to determine the results of the adventurers' decisions.

items.name: Adjudicate the Rules
items.entry: You oversee how the group uses the game's rules, making sure the rules serve the group's fun. Tutorials in each adventure teach you some of those rules, but you'll want to reference the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} to better understand them.

entries.name: Keep It Secret
entries: Secrets and reveals are important DM tools. If you read any of the DM-only material and still want to experience the adventure as a player, you can—just don't let this knowledge influence your character's actions or behavior. More importantly, don't spoil any surprises for your fellow players!

entries.name: Swapping Roles
entries: Playing a character and being the Dungeon Master aren't permanent roles. Trading places is easy.

Whenever you begin play or whenever the Player Characters decide to leave one of the adventure's three settings—the Caves of Chaos, the Keep on the Borderlands, or the Wilderness—determine who will be the DM for the upcoming section. The previous DM can either make a new character of a level equal to the other characters or play as the new DM's now-available character.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: Once you've chosen the DM, follow the instructions below to begin play.

entries.name: If You're a Character
entries: Follow these steps to create your character:

items: {@b Choose your Class}. Pick one of the classes from the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} as your character's Class.
{@b Choose your Origin}. Pick one Background and one Species. Together, these form your character's Origin.
{@b Name Your Character}. Choose a name for your character. The name can be whatever you like. When you're ready, introduce your character to the other players and your DM.

entries.name: If You're the Dungeon Master
entries: Follow these steps if you're the DM:

items: {@b Review the {@i D&D Beyond Basic Rules}.} Familiarize yourself with the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} and its organization. You don't need to memorize every rule before you play, but you should understand the rhythm of play and where to find relevant information when needed.

{@b Choose an Adventure Setting}. Pick one of the three adventure locations and read its introduction. If this is your first time playing D&D, the {@adventure Wilderness|HotB|3} section is a good place to start, followed by the {@adventure Keep on the Borderlands|HotB|2}. Each section contains a tutorial location with sidebars that help you run the adventure.

entries: Now you're ready to play D&D!

entries.name: Play On D&D Beyond
entries: Bring your adventure to life with the Maps VTT, the official virtual tabletop for {@i Dungeons & Dragons}. Access it at {@link DnDBeyond.com/games|https://www.dndbeyond.com/games} and you'll find this quick-play adventure already set up—complete with maps, monsters, and tokens ready for your party to play. Want to make it your own? Use those same components (and any others in your collection) to forge entirely new adventures all in Maps VTT.

entries.name: The Adventure
entries: {@i Heroes of the Borderlands} is for two to four characters of levels 1–3. The adventure has no overarching plot. While there are conflicts and secrets to uncover, the story that emerges is the one your group experiences.

The adventure is divided into three self-contained sections, each of which features a different area. You don't need to read one section to understand the others, and you can play and revisit them in any order. The adventure areas are as follows:
{@adventure The Caves of Chaos|HotB|1} tempt adventurers with riches and glory, obtainable by any who dare brave these monster-filled caverns.
{@adventure The Keep on the Borderlands|HotB|2} is a fortified settlement where the party can rest, purchase goods and services, and interact with locals.
{@adventure The Wilderness|HotB|3} lies beyond the ken of law. Friends, foes, and surprises await explorers who traverse these untamed wilds.

Over the course of the adventure, the characters might visit these areas more than once. They don't have to complete all the encounters in one section before exploring a different corner of the Borderlands.

entries.name: About the Original
entries: The adventure in this set reimagines {@i B2: The Keep on the Borderlands} for the current edition of the game. First printed in 1979, the original adventure was designed for the {@i Dungeons & Dragons Basic Set}, which introduced new players and Dungeon Masters to the world of D&D—much as this set does.

data.name: Caves of Chaos
entries: Beyond the Keep on the Borderlands hide the Caves of Chaos, a network of monster-infested caves where by a wicked cult lurks. Danger awaits foolhardy adventurers who enter the caves—but so do treasure and glory.

entries.name: DM Secret
entries: This is for the Dungeon Master's eyes only. Unless text appears in a read-aloud box (like the one below), don't read it to the players.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: The {@adventure Caves of Chaos Map|HotB|1|Map: Caves of Chaos (DM Version)} displays all the locations characters can visit in the Caves of Chaos. The player version of this map doesn't reveal the caves' contents or names, only the cave mouths and their respective elements. Share that map with your players.
To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

You pass through a dense forest of gnarled trees with grasping roots, the woods twisting as if to ward you off. Undeterred, you emerge from the tangled thicket into a stark ravine. Its rocky walls rise steeply one hundred feet or so above. Several dark cave mouths pockmark the walls at varying heights. The air is stale and quiet.
Among the rocks and dead wood that litter the ravine's floor are the bones of animals and explorers, picked clean by scavengers. Vultures leer at you hungrily from barren branches.
Where do you want to go?

The Caves of Chaos table summarizes the caves in the order they appear within this. Each cave provides approximately 60–90 minutes of gameplay. The DM version of the map includes the suggested minimum level for each cave; for example, the characters should be level 2 or higher before entering cave F.
Cave A functions as a tutorial with helpful sidebars. If this is your first time as the DM, encourage the players to start there. Otherwise, have them choose a cave shown on the map.
Once the player characters choose a cave, navigate to that cave's section.

entries.caption: Caves of Chaos
rows: A band of kobolds stole a dragon egg, and it hatched!
Mischievous elementals lair in this flooded cave.
A former wizard turned monster studies in this makeshift lab.
A gang of violent goblins throw a raucous party for their leader.
A hulking, irritable mercenary lives in this shallow cave.
Militant hobgoblins have fortified this cave.
A fearsome owlbear lurks in its den.
A malevolent minotaur prowls this ruined cave.
Vicious hunters scour this forsaken shrine.
A dastardly cult performs unholy rites in this temple.

entries.name: Exploring the Caves
entries: As the characters explore a cave, the characters progress through its areas, as depicted on the cave's map.

entries.name: Cave Descriptions
entries: Each description of a cave has these sections:

items.name: Getting Started
items.entry: This section provides instructions for the DM and introduces the cave with thematic read-aloud text.

items.name: Features
items.entry: Important features about the cave, such as its lighting, appear here.

items.name: Locations
items.entry: This section details the cave's areas and its contents, including any monsters.

items.name: DM's Map of the Cave
items.entry: This map displays the locations of monsters, traps, and treasure within the cave.

entries.name: Rhythm of Play
entries: When the characters enter an area for the first time, do the following:

items.name: Step 1:
items.entry: Describe the Area. Describe what the characters perceive in the area. Focus on what they see, hear, or smell.

items.name: Step 2:
items.entry: Ask the Players, "What Do You Do?" Players tell you what their characters do or say.

items.name: Step 3:
items.entry: Narrate the Results. The player characters reap the consequences of their actions as outlined in the text. This might involve one or more {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} (see the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}) to determine the outcome. It could also lead to combat (see below).

items.name: Step 4:
items.entry: Repeat. When the player characters reach another area of the cave, repeat this procedure.

entries.name: Combat
entries: Though it's possible to avoid combat with many of the caves' occupants, the characters eventually will clash with creatures that can't be reasoned with. The text states when a monster might start combat. When a fight breaks out, see the "{@book Combat|XPHB|1|Combat}" section in the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}.
The following stat blocks are used in this section:

entries.name: Resting
entries: Threats abound within the caves. The characters can take only {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short Rests} within them. To take a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, they must first exit any cave they're in. For more on {@book resting|XPHB|1|Resting}, see the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}.

entries.name: Leaving the Caves
entries: The characters can leave the Caves of Chaos any time they choose, provided they aren't inside a cave or engaged in combat. If they return to a cave later, it is as they left it.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: In this adventure, the characters can gain levels by completing caves. To complete a cave, the characters must explore every area within it.
The characters gain levels by achieving the following milestones:

items.name: Completing Two Caves
items.entry: After the characters fully explore two caves, they advance to level 2.

items.name: Completing Three More Caves
items.entry: After the characters fully explore a total of five caves, they advance to level 3.

entries: Each of these level advancements occurs only once. If the characters are already level 3, they don't gain levels by exploring the caves.

entries.name: A: Kobold Lair
entries: A band of kobolds recently stole a dragon egg and brought it to these caves to eat. But when the egg hatched and a screeching dragon wyrmling emerged, the kobolds quickly realized they bit off more than they could chew.
The kobolds tried to appease the fussy wyrmling with treasure, but they can't agree on what to do next. Should they return the wyrmling to its nest, or should they raise it themselves?

entries.name: Summary
entries: The beginning of each cave presents its central conflict, as well as optional ways to increase or decrease the difficulty. If the characters are level 1, don't increase the difficulty.

entries.name: Bold Terms
entries: When a monster's name appears in {@b Bold} type, that's a visual cue to say, "Hey, DM, you should get this stat block ready. You're going to need it."

You can add monsters, such as {@creature Giant Fire Beetle|XMM|Giant Fire Beetles}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can reduce the number of {@creature Kobold Warrior|XMM|Kobold Warriors} to make it easier and shorter.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
A tunnel made of hard-packed earth leads into darkness. The cave echoes with high-pitched bickering overtopped by a loud, bestial squeal.

entries.name: Boxed Text
entries: Text that appears in a box like the one in this section is meant to be read aloud or paraphrased for the players when their characters first arrive at a location or under a specific circumstance, as described in the text.
The sounds come from the quarreling kobolds in {@area area A4|039|x} and the crying wyrmling in {@area area A5|03e|x}.

entries.name: Kobold Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 10 feet high.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The cave has rough stone walls and a dirt floor. The floor is littered with gnawed animal bones and junk collected by the kobolds.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Features
entries: This section presents special features about the location. Some of these exist to help you set the mood—you might describe the crunch of animal bones under the characters' feet—while others detail important rules, such as secret doors and how to find them.

entries.name: Kobold Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map A.

entries.name: Exploration and Movement
entries: Exploration is open-ended; the players don't take turns moving around the dungeon the way they do in combat. As they explore, direct the players to freely move around on the map, but stop them when they reach the entrance (area A1).

entries.name: A1: Entrance

entries: A twenty-foot-long tunnel leads into the cave.
This tunnel contains a hidden pit trap, as detailed below.

entries.name: Pit Trap
entries: This 10-foot-deep pit is covered by a large, dirty cloth. When a character steps on the cloth, it gives way, dumping the character into the pit, at which point the pit is no longer hidden. A creature that falls into the pit takes {@damage 1d6} Bludgeoning damage.
Rules for detecting and escaping the trap are as follows:

items.name: Detecting the Trap
items.entry: The pit is poorly camouflaged. A character who examines the trapped area easily discovers the pit. Once detected, the pit can be safely avoided by sidling along its perimeter.

items.name: Escaping the Pit
items.entry: The pit's walls have cracks big enough to serve as handholds, allowing trapped creatures to climb out easily.

entries: A character falling into the pit alerts the kobold in area A2, who approaches the pit and crows, "Got 'em!" The encounter in that area then occurs here.

entries.name: Rhythm of Play
entries: Here's an example of how the pit trap in area A1 might play out:

items: {@b Describe the Scene}. Read the boxed text aloud.

{@b Ask the Players, "What Do You Do?"} You might ask how the player characters enter the cave. If they charge brashly ahead, the character in the lead falls into the pit. However, if a player says their character looks carefully, they spot the trap.
{@b Narrate the Results}. Once the pit's presence becomes known, describe the pit and the narrow ledge around it.

entries: Once the players know the pit is there, ask them how their characters bypass it. If they come up with a creative solution not described in the text, err on the side of leniency and fun. Whenever you think a rule might be necessary, see the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}.
Repeat this process for the other areas in this cave, modifying it based on their contents.

entries.name: A2: Guard Nook

entries: A small, bipedal reptile stands guard in this nook.

A {@creature Kobold Warrior|XMM} keeps watch in this nook. The guard is initially {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward intruders, but it's also naive. Rather than alerting the other kobolds when it spots the characters, it marches toward them and asks what they want.

entries.name: Attitudes
entries: Every creature has a starting attitude toward the characters: {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}, {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}, or {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} (see the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}). Regardless, creatures defend themselves in combat.
As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to appease the kobold and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character tricks the kobold with an outlandish lie.
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}).} The character amuses the kobold with a jaunty tune.
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}).} The character convinces the kobold the party means it no harm.

On a successful check, the character improves the kobold's attitude to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}, and the kobold grants them entry, warning them cryptically about the "many-legs" to the west (see area A3). On a failed check, the kobold becomes {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} and flees toward {@area area A4|039|x}, yelping a call to arms.

entries.name: Ability Checks
entries: When the outcome of an action is uncertain, the game uses a {@dice d20} roll to determine success or failure. This is called a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}. An ability check is one type of D20 Test. Here's how to run the ability check in area A2:

items: {@b Describe the Scene}. Paint a mental picture of the kobold either by describing its words and actions or by actively roleplaying it—giving it a voice like an actor in a role.
{@b Ask the Players, "What Do You Do?"} If the players aren't sure what to do, suggest ways they could respond to the kobold, like trying to deceive or persuade it.

{@b Narrate the Results}. The Difficulty Class (DC) for each listed ability check is 10. If the total of the {@dice d20} and its modifiers equals or exceeds 10, the check succeeds. On a 9 or lower, it fails. In either case, the area's description tells you what happens.

items.name: Example
items.entry: A Rogue tries to deceive the kobold with a Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check. The player rolls a {@dice d20} and adds their character's {@skill Deception|XPHB} modifier (+4) for a total of 14. The check succeeds—the kobold believes the lie!

entries.name: A3: Centipedes' Den

entries: This cave contains heaps of waste. Two giant centipedes skitter about, picking at the refuse.

Two {@creature Giant Centipede|XMM|Giant Centipedes} scavenge this cave. The centipedes are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures and fight anyone who enters their den.

The kobolds are afraid of the centipedes—a fact they report to any who mention the beasts. If the characters slay the centipedes and show proof to a kobold, this deed earns the kobold's respect, improving its attitude toward them to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}.

entries.name: Combat
entries: Though the characters can avoid combat elsewhere, the centipedes in area A3 fight them on sight. Here's how that might play out:

items: {@b Describe the Scene}. Read the boxed text aloud. Then say, "Roll Initiative!" to signal the start of combat. Roll once for both centipedes, which act on the same turn.

{@b Players React}. In combat, the characters and the centipedes act on their turns. Use the "{@book Combat|XPHB|1|Combat}" section in the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} to run this encounter.

entries.name: A4: Common Area

entries: This common area contains straw beds and a pile of junk. Five small, bipedal reptiles pace about the cave, arguing loudly.

Five {@creature Kobold Warrior|XMM|Kobold Warriors} are trying to decide whether to keep the wyrmling or return it to its nest. They cease bickering when they notice the characters. The kobolds' initial attitude is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}. If they learn the characters eliminated the guard in {@area area A2|02f|x}, these kobolds are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Stashed in the junk pile are 25 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Treasure entries like this describe loot in an area. Usually, treasure consists of Gold Pieces (GP), magic items, or both.

Whenever a player character finds gold, give that player Gold Pieces equal to the listed value, which is tracked on their character sheet. For magic items, roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

items.name: Share the Wealth
items.entry: Encourage players to split treasure among the characters as evenly as possible. This is especially important for magic items, which are seldom awarded.

items.name: Spending Gold Pieces
items.entry: Opportunities to spend gold in the Caves of Chaos are rare, but the {@adventure Keep on the Borderlands|HotB|2} contains plenty of goods and services available for purchase.

entries.name: A5: Larder
entries: The stone door to this room is ajar. A persistent, ear-splitting cry emanates within. When the characters enter, read the following text aloud:

This chamber contains barrels and sacks of dried and salted meats, grains, and vegetables. A dragon wyrmling with copper scales sits on a scant pile of coins and eggshell fragments in the corner of the room, shrieking endlessly.
Two small, bipedal reptiles with worried expressions deposit handfuls of coins and junk at the creature's feet.

Two {@creature Kobold Warrior|XMM|Kobold Warriors} attempt to comfort the crying {@creature Copper Dragon Wyrmling|XMM} by adding treasure to its meager hoard. It isn't going well. The kobolds and the wyrmling are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward all other creatures.

entries.name: Soothing the Wyrmling
entries: The wyrmling knows the kobolds aren't its parents, but it doesn't know where its nest is. The wyrmling doesn't yet have a name, which only compounds its misery.
As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to calm the wyrmling and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character mollifies the wyrmling with a promise they don't intend to keep.
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}).} The character assures the wyrmling they're here to help.
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}).} The character soothes the wyrmling with a gentle lullaby.

A character who offers the wyrmling at least 10 GP has Advantage on this check. On a successful check, the wyrmling stops wailing, and its attitude improves to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}, as do the attitudes of all kobolds in the cave. The wyrmling then asks the characters whether it should stay with the kobolds or return home. The kobolds honor the wyrmling's choice, which corresponds with the characters' recommendation.

entries.name: Advantage/Disadvantage
entries: Sometimes a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB} is modified by special situations called {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} and {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}, which reflect positive and negative circumstances, respectively. See the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} for more on Advantage and Disadvantage.
In area A5, if a character gives the dragon wyrmling at least 10 GP, that character has Advantage on an ability check to influence it.

items.name: Roll Two D20s
items.entry: When a roll has either Advantage or Disadvantage, roll a second {@dice d20} when you make the roll. Use the higher of the two rolls if you have Advantage, and use the lower roll if you have Disadvantage.

items.name: Example
items.entry: A Cleric gives the wyrmling 10 GP and then hums a tune to soothe it. The Cleric takes the {@action Influence|XPHB} action and makes a Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}) check with Advantage. The player rolls two d20s: 15 and 6. The player uses the higher roll and adds the Cleric's {@skill Performance|XPHB} modifier (+2) for a total of 17, which exceeds the DC of 10, and the check succeeds. If the check had been made with Disadvantage instead, the total of 8 would've failed.

entries: On a failed check, or if the characters try to steal from its meager hoard, the wyrmling fights. The cowardly kobolds abstain from battle. If the wyrmling defeats all the characters, they wake up 1 hour later outside the cave with 1 Hit Point each.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: The wyrmling's Acid Breath action (see the wyrmling's stat block) prompts another type of {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}: a saving throw. Saving throws—also called saves—are named for the ability modifiers they use; in this case, characters use Dexterity to dodge an exhalation of acid. If a character is targeted by this effect, the player rolls a {@dice d20} and adds the character's Dexterity save modifier. A save's result is detailed in the effect that caused it.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The wyrmling's hoard consists of 25 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: B: Mephit Lair
entries: Sturdy fortifications and clean water make this abandoned subterranean outpost an appealing den for thieves and monsters. Before the prior inhabitants left, they stored some enticing treasure here, guarded by a monstrous shape-shifter called a mimic. Since then, a trio of impish elementals and kuo-toa fanatics have made the cave their home.

You can add monsters, such as {@creature Giant Centipede|XMM|Giant Centipedes}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can remove the {@creature Kuo-Toa Marauder|HotB|Kuo-Toa Marauders} or one of the {@creature Steam Mephit|XMM|Steam Mephits} to make it easier and shorter.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
Walls of mortared stone and cracked flagstone tiles form the interior of this cave, creating the impression of a subterranean fortress. Water trickles steadily somewhere in the cave.
Water from the broken fountain in {@area area B7|055|x} floods a chamber to the south ({@area area B5|051|x}). The dribbling fountain can be heard throughout the cave.

entries.name: Mephit Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 10 feet high.

items.name: Door
items.entry: The door to {@area area B8|057|x} is made from reinforced wood; it's closed but unlocked.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The cave's walls are made of smooth, mortared stones with patches of unworked rock.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Mephit Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map B.

entries.name: B1: Entrance

entries: An arrow slit interrupts the wall at this junction.

The arrow slit is linked to area B2. If the characters enter the cave carrying a source of {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} or talking loudly, the slit begins to vent harmless steam as the {@creature Steam Mephit|XMM} in that area approaches the opening and observes them. The slit provides the mephit with {@table Cover|XPHB|Three-Quarters Cover}.

entries.name: B2: Balistraria

entries: Steam fills this stone alcove, which looks out to the cave's entrance through a thin vertical slit.

Defenders can watch the cave entrance from this alcove. A {@creature Steam Mephit|XMM} flits about the area. It ostensibly watches for intruders coming from area B1, but it is bored and barely fulfilling its duties. The mephit is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} but defends itself in combat.

If the mephit sees the characters enter the cave, it peers at them through the arrow slit and whistles like a teakettle to entice them to approach. If a character comes within 5 feet of the slit, the mephit exhales a 15-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone} of harmless steam and snickers at the character's reaction.

If the characters approach from the other side of the alcove, the mephit feigns innocence. It then tries to lure them to the old barrack ({@area area B6|053|x}) to be ambushed by the kuo-toa that lurk there.

entries.name: B3: Prison Cells
entries: Four cold cells line one wall of this chamber. Floor-to-ceiling iron bars partition the cells, which are unlocked and devoid of valuables. Two of the cells contain unidentifiable skeletal remains draped in moth-eaten rags.

entries.name: B4: Old Armory
entries: Cobwebbed weapon racks and rusty suits of armor lie scattered about this armory. None of the items is salvageable.

entries.name: B5: Flooded Room

entries: Water trickles into this spacious chamber from the north, forming a shallow pool. A small, winged creature made of hissing steam zips above the water in pursuit of a tiny croaking frog.
Warm spring water streams into this room from {@area area B7|055|x}, forming a 1-foot-deep pool here. The pool is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

A {@creature Steam Mephit|XMM} toys with a panicked frog in the water. The mephit is initially {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters and remains that way unless they try to spoil its fun, which provokes the hot-tempered elemental to start combat. If a fight breaks out, the mephits in {@area areas B2|04d|x} and B7 quickly join the fray.

entries.name: B6: Old Barrack

entries: Ruined cots are heaped near the corners of this chamber, which features a natural ceiling. Two slimy humanoids with fishlike heads use spears to carve strange symbols on the cave walls.

Two {@creature Kuo-Toa Marauder|HotB|Kuo-Toa Marauders} scrawl rupestrian gibberish on the walls of this run-down barrack. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} kuo-toa fight the characters on sight, hoping to capture them alive and hold them in the prison cells ({@area area B3|04f|x}). The room is otherwise empty.

entries.name: B7: Broken Fountain

entries: A badly broken stone fountain burbles in an alcove at the upper end of this sloped hallway.
Warm water bubbles from an underground spring into this ruined fountain. It flows south and pools in {@area area B5|051|x}.

Unless it was drawn elsewhere, a {@creature Steam Mephit|XMM} lurks near the fountain, quietly mesmerized by the fountain's burbling. The mephit behaves similarly to the one in area B5, starting combat with the characters if disturbed. If a fight breaks out, the mephits in {@area areas B2|04d|x} and B5 join the fray.

entries.name: B8: Vault

entries: Dust coats this plundered vault, which is mostly empty. Two chests rest along the east wall.

One of the chests is fake—a hungry {@creature Mimic|XMM} has altered its shape to resemble the mundane container beside it. The mimic ambushes any creature that comes within 5 feet of it. It fights to the death.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The real treasure chest contains 150 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: C: Nothic Lair
entries: An evil wizard used these caverns to conduct foul experiments. The last of these destroyed the wizard's memory and transformed her into a cyclopic monster called a nothic. By studying arcane secrets, the nothic hopes to regain its memories and attain enough power to rule the Caves of Chaos.

Recently, a carrion crawler slithered into the cave and interrupted the nothic's research. Unwilling to confront the creature directly, the nothic is now trapped in its laboratory as it concocts a solution.

You can add monsters, such as {@creature Stirge|XMM|Stirges}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can remove the {@creature Animated Flying Sword|XMM} to make it easier and shorter.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
The entrance to this cave is flanked by carved stone blocks etched with strange geometric patterns. You hear sounds of something scuttling across the stone inside the cave.
The sounds come from the carrion crawler in the hallway ({@area area C4|067|x}).

entries.name: Nothic Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 10 feet high.

items.name: Doors
items.entry: Doors throughout the cave are made of reinforced wood with iron hinges.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The cave has mostly smooth stone walls with patches of unworked stone. The smooth stone walls are carved with geometric patterns and indecipherable runes.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Nothic Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map C.

entries.name: C1: Entrance

entries: The symbols etched into the entrance extend into the cave.

A character who examines the symbols and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check recognizes them as arcane runes designed to ward the cave against magical scrutiny. The runes are unfinished, so they have no effect.

entries.name: C2: Ritual Chamber

entries: Half-melted black candles surround a circle of arcane symbols scribed on the floor in white chalk. Scorch marks mar the floor inside the circle.
A character who examines the circle and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check determines it was the site of an arcane ritual that went horribly wrong.

entries.name: C3: Library

entries: Moldy leather-bound books line stone shelves carved into the walls of this underground library. A tome with an iron-plated cover lies open on a table near the north wall.
The nothic occasionally performs research here.

entries.name: Books
entries: The books in this room cover topics related to alchemy, geometry, and metallurgy. They are hard to parse, and none of them are valuable to the characters.

entries.name: Iron Tome
entries: The open tome describes the Chaos Bell, a wicked bell said to attract monsters from near and far. The book claims the bell's toll can even wake the dead. According to the book, the bell can be destroyed only by submerging it in a sacred spring hidden in the forests of the Borderlands.

entries.name: C4: Hallway

entries: A massive, tentacled grub with dozens of legs creeps along the ceiling of this long hallway.
A {@creature Carrion Crawler|XMM} clings to the hall's ceiling. It is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures and fights them on sight.

entries.name: C5: Wizard's Laboratory

entries: Esoteric apparatuses and strange reagents line worktables and shelves in this laboratory. A cyclopic creature paces about the room before a chalkboard. A floating sword guards the creature.

A {@creature Nothic|XMM} broods over the invader in the hallway (see area C4). Protecting the nothic is an {@creature Animated Flying Sword|XMM} that obeys the nothic's commands. Both are initially {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters.

entries.name: Chalkboard
entries: Scrawled on the chalkboard are a map of this cave and indecipherable formulas.

entries.name: Eye for an Eye
entries: The nothic wants to research in peace, which it can't do as long as the carrion crawler threatens its lair. If the characters don't fight the nothic, it asks them for help.

If the characters slay the carrion crawler, the nothic offers the party the treasure in the cell (area C6). If asked about the dead dwarf there, the nothic takes credit for thwarting the meddlesome thief.

entries.name: Key
entries: On a table is a key to the storage room ({@area area C7|071|x}). To swipe the key without the nothic noticing, a character must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check. On a failed check, the nothic and its sword start combat.

entries.name: C6: Cell

entries: Iron bars divide this chamber, forming a cell to the south. Flies buzz around a corpse sprawled on the floor of the cell.

The cell is unlocked. Inside lies the rotting corpse of a dwarf explorer who came to the Caves of Chaos in search of riches but perished ten days ago. A character who examines the corpse and succeeds on a {@dc 10} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check deduces that the dwarf died from Necrotic damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The dead explorer's belongings include 60 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: C7: Storage Room
entries: The door to this room is locked. The key can be found in the laboratory ({@area area C5|069|x}). As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, a character can pick the lock with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check using Thieves' Tools or force open the door with a successful {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: An unlocked chest against the east wall contains 100 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: D: Goblin Lair
entries: A violent band of goblin warriors lives in this cave. It's the goblin boss's birthday, and she demands a celebration! Engrossed in the revelry, the goblins ignore their recent captive: a dwarf named Vinx.

You can add monsters to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult. The goblins might have invited {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM|Hobgoblin Warriors} from the adjacent cave ({@area cave F|097|x}) as party guests or bodyguards. To make the scenario easier and shorter, reduce the number of {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM|Goblin Warriors}.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: This cave is connected to {@area cave E|087|x} via the secret door in {@adventure area D5|HotB|1|D5: Webbed Cavern} (see {@adventure map D|HotB|1|Map D: Goblin Lair (DM's Version) View Without Tokens}); characters can also enter from {@area cave F|097|x} through the hallway west of {@adventure area D4|HotB|1|D4: Boss's Room}. If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:
Torches illuminate this stinking cave. A horrendous racket of discordant voices echoes within. The voices appear to be singing—quite badly.
The "music" emanates from the boss's room (area {@dice D4}), where off-key goblins commemorate their leader in song. The singing continues for 1 minute, then ends with a din of celebratory yips.

entries.name: Goblin Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 10 feet high.

items.name: Surroundings
items.entry: The cave has walls of rough-hewn stone and a dirt floor. It stinks of old food and soiled clothes, which are strewn about the cave.

items.name: Doors and Secret Door
items.entry: Doors in the cave are made of rough wood. The secret door in {@adventure area D5|HotB|1|D5: Webbed Cavern} blends in with the surrounding wall. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to scan that area for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: Torches in wall sconces throughout the cave fill it with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Goblin Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map D.

entries.name: D1: Entrance

entries: The walls here are daubed with crude paintings of grinning goblins with pointy hats. Scrawled above the art are the words, "hoppee birthday!"
The goblins painted the celebratory drawings.

entries.name: D2: Dead-End Tunnel

entries: This tunnel leads to a dead end with some old barrels. An exasperated dwarf is tied up beside them. "A little help here?" she asks as she squirms.

The captive is {@creature Vinx|HotB}, a dwarf spelunker. Vinx came to this cave in search of a stolen family tapestry, but the goblins captured her. Vinx is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters and has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition while bound.

Vinx assures the characters that she's a capable explorer who can hold her own in a fight, but some quests can't be completed alone. If they help her recover the tapestry, she promises a hefty reward.
The barrels are mostly filled with crooked spears and old arrows that are unusable.

entries.name: Freeing Vinx
entries: As an action, a character can untie Vinx or cut her bonds (no check required). If freed, Vinx gratefully accompanies the characters as they explore the cave and fights alongside them until they all reemerge in the valley.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Vinx stashed a magic item at the bottom of one of the barrels before she was captured; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item. If freed, Vinx discreetly fishes the item out of the barrel and keeps it on her person until the characters find her family's tapestry (see {@adventure area D4|HotB|1|D4: Boss's Room}).

entries.name: D3: Common Room

entries: Heaps of soiled bedding, tables, and stools are scattered around the room. Clumsily wrapped presents with tattered ribbons are piled on one table, along with a half-eaten cake that looks like it was dropped.
These goblin gifts include a bag of assorted teeth, a moist wad of thoughtfully pre-chewed jerky, and a foul-smelling mushroom. The cake appears professionally baked but poorly handled.

entries.name: D4: Boss's Room

entries: In this rowdy chamber, a bossy goblin with a party hat and a kazoo sits on a wooden throne with a lopsided cushion. Goblin celebrants with cake-stained faces dance below.

A {@creature Goblin Boss|XMM} and four {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM|Goblin Warriors} are here celebrating the boss's birthday. The goblins are initially {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters.
When the goblins notice the characters, they stop dancing. Read or paraphrase the following text:
The goblin on the throne leaps to her feet and barks, "BREE-YARK! This is {@i my} party, and I don't remember inviting {@i you}!"
The goblins brandish their weapons.

{@b "Hoppee Birthday!"} As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to defuse the tension and make a {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. A character who offers the boss an impressive birthday present—such as 10 GP, a magic item, or one of the gifts from area {@dice D3}—automatically succeeds on this check.

On a successful check, the goblins' attitudes improve to {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}, and the boss invites the characters to join her birthday celebration. On a failed check, the goblins fight the party crashers.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Stashed under the throne's ragged cushion are a fine tapestry sewn with silver and gold threads and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item. The tapestry belongs to Vinx and is worth 90 GP.

If the characters give the tapestry to Vinx, she rewards them with the magic item from {@adventure area D2|HotB|1|D2: Dead-End Tunnel}. However, if she learns the characters intend to keep the tapestry, she hotly demands they return the family heirloom and fights them if they refuse.

entries.name: D5: Webbed Cavern

entries: Webs drape the western half of this musky cave.
A {@creature Giant Spider|XMM} lurks in a tunnel to the south. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} spider ambushes all non-goblins in its den.

entries.name: Webs
entries: The webs are {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}, but they aren't strong enough to restrain anyone. Each 10-foot-cube of webs has AC 10; HP 5; Vulnerability to Fire damage; and Immunity to Bludgeoning, Piercing, Poison, and Psychic damage.

entries.name: E: Ogre Lair
entries: An ogre mercenary named Oggdug recently formed an alliance with a red dragon wyrmling who aims to rule the Caves of Chaos. The dragon, Cindertooth, serves Oggdug as an attack dog and companion—for now. Cindertooth tolerates Oggdug so long as the ogre supplies him with gold and spoils for his growing hoard. Player characters might hire the ogre for a short time.

You can add monsters to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult. One or more {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM|Goblin Warriors} or {@creature Kobold Warrior|XMM|Kobold Warriors} might be here soliciting the ogre's services. Conversely, you can remove the {@creature Red Dragon Wyrmling|XMM} to make the scenario easier and shorter. Cindertooth might be away when the characters first explore this cave.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: This cave is connected to {@area cave D|073|x} via the secret door in {@area area E3|093|x} (see map E). If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:
This large cave exudes a strong, sour odor. Half-gnawed hunks of meat from sloppily butchered and charred animals litter the area.
The cave's occupants are responsible for the mess.

entries.name: Ogre Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 15 feet high.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The dirt floor of this natural cave is stained with blood from past battles.

items.name: Secret Door
items.entry: The secret door in {@area area E3|093|x} blends in with the surrounding wall. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to scan that area for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check. Oggdug knows about the door but doesn't use it due to its narrowness and the spider den on the other side (see {@area cave D|073|x}).

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: During the day, natural light provides {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} in the cave. At night, its denizens rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Ogre Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map E.

entries.name: E1: Entrance

entries: Flies buzz around the rotting carcass of some unrecognizable beast outside the cave mouth.
The carcass conceals a hidden snare trap. The trap is depicted on map E.

entries.name: Snare Trap
entries: This trap consists of bent saplings and a loop of gore-encrusted rope. A creature that moves, prods, or otherwise disturbs the meat must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or be hoisted 5 feet into the air. The hoisted creature has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until it gets free.
Rules for detecting, disabling, and escaping the trap are as follows:

items.name: Detect and Disable
items.entry: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can examine the carcass and make a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, detecting the trap on a successful check. Once detected, the trap can be disabled by a character who takes the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check; failing this check triggers the trap.

items.name: Escaping the Trap
items.entry: As an action, a creature {@condition Restrained|XPHB} by the trap can free itself by cutting the rope or by slipping out with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check.

entries: If the trap is triggered, the noise alerts the ogre in area E2, who stomps out of the cave to investigate. The encounter in that area then occurs here.

entries.name: E2: Ogre Mercenary's Den

entries: Thick, lumpy bearskins cover the floor of this cave, but they're hardly visible beneath the hulking, potbellied giant that lies atop it, picking his teeth with a rusty sword.

Oggdug, an {@creature Ogre|XMM}, reclines on the bearskins. He is initially {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters, but if they approach peacefully, Oggdug assumes they must want to hire him for mercenary work. He tells the characters to cough up some coin or get out, threatening to clobber any who refuse.

A character can shift Oggdug's attitude from Hostile to {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} by hiring him (see the "Hiring the Ogre" section below) or taking the {@action Influence|XPHB} action to make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character dupes the ogre with a clever ruse or outlandish lie.
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}).} The character amuses the ogre with a small performance, such as a dance or magic trick.
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}).} The character convinces the ogre the party means him no harm.

On a failed check, or if a character tries to undercut Oggdug's price, the ogre starts combat, grumbling that the characters are "puny cheapskates." If the ogre drops to half his Hit Points or fewer, he calls to Cindertooth in area E3 for aid.

entries.name: Hiring the Ogre
entries: Oggdug is accustomed to other denizens of the Caves of Chaos hiring him for mercenary work. His rate is 50 GP per job, but first-time customers get a 50 percent discount (25 GP). Cindertooth gets half of Oggdug's earnings.

If the party pays the ogre his asking price, he joins them for a single fight in any of the caves except for the two caves he says are off-limits (cave G and cave K). After the fight, the ogre returns to this cave unless the characters pay him for another bout. The second time the characters hire the ogre and every time afterward, his rate is 50 GP per job.

{@b "Oggdug Sad."} If a character asks Oggdug about either of the off-limits caves, the ogre sighs mournfully and tells them his tragic story. Oggdug once shared this cave with his older brother, Zurf, before Zurf was killed by an owlbear near its den ({@area cave G|0ab|x}). Cultists later animated Zurf's half-eaten corpse, which now guards the cultists' lair ({@area cave K|0f6|x}). Oggdug now shuns both caves.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The filthy bearskins conceal a pile of equine bones, a wheel of cheese, a keg of brandy, and a lumpy sack containing 60 GP. The ogre warns anyone who goes near the bearskins that he'll "give 'em a good stomping" if they continue snooping. He makes good on his threat.

entries.name: E3: Dragon's Den

entries: This spacious cavern contains battered armor, broken weapons, casks of ale and mead, and other supplies. A red-scaled dragon glowers down at the chamber from a rocky perch ten feet above the cave floor.
Cindertooth, a {@creature Red Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, dwells in this cavern. The dragon is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward creatures other than Oggdug.
When Cindertooth notices the characters, he flies down to scold them for trespassing. He demands each character pay him 10 GP as tribute or face his fiery wrath.

A character can attempt to avoid Cindertooth's toll by making a {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. Characters who appeal to the dragon's ego through flattery have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on this check. On a successful check, or if the character pays Cindertooth, the dragon tells them to leave this cave while they still can. On a failed check, or if the characters don't heed Cindertooth's warning, he starts combat.

entries.name: Fighting Cindertooth
entries: Combat here draws the attention of Oggdug, who stomps into this area and joins the fray. At your discretion, the ogre might fight alongside the characters in hopes of claiming the dragon's hoard for himself.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The provisions and supplies in this room were taken from travelers and adventurers who crossed paths with Cindertooth. All the equipment here was ruined beyond repair in battle.

Amid the dragon's spoils are 50 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item. The dragon fights any creature that steals from its hoard.

entries.name: F: Hobgoblin Lair
entries: Hobgoblins quartered in this cave recently suffered heavy losses, including their former captain. Only four hobgoblins remain. They've fortified their outpost and drafted a voracious ooze to guard it.

You can add monsters, such as allied {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM|Goblin Warriors}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can remove some monsters to make it easier and shorter. One or two {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM|Hobgoblin Warriors} might be out on a patrol elsewhere.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: This cave is connected to {@area cave D|073|x} via the hall east of {@area area F2|0a3|x} (see {@adventure map F|HotB|1|Map F: Hobgoblin Lair (DM's Version) View Without Tokens}). If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:
A stout, ironbound door seals this cave mouth. Bleached skulls line niches outside the entrance. A bloodstained sign on the door reads, "Come in! We'd like to have you for dinner!"
The hobgoblins don't eat people, but they use the sign's gruesome implication to scare intruders.

entries.name: Hobgoblin Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 10 feet high.

items.name: Doors
items.entry: The cave's doors are made of oak planks bound with iron. They are unlocked.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The cave is carved from stone. It is scrupulously clean. The hobgoblins keep their areas tidy, and the gelatinous cube in {@area area F2|0a3|x} sweeps up anything in its path.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Hobgoblin Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map F.

entries.name: F1: Entrance

entries: An armored goblinoid warrior with red-orange skin and a bow stands behind a rickety barricade of interlocking spears. "Halt!" she commands. "State your business or face the wrath of our battalion—thirty hobgoblins strong."

A {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM} stands guard behind a pair of spear barricades (see the "{@area Spear Barricade|09f|x}" sidebar). The sentry is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward intruders and tries to delay them through interrogation until the gelatinous cube in {@area area F2|0a3|x} arrives here to dispatch them.

The sentry is lying about how many hobgoblins remain. Weakened by their recent loss, the hobgoblins fear marauders and try to present a strong front. A character who doubts the sentry can take the {@action Search|XPHB} action and make a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check; a successful check discerns the lie.

As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to pacify the sentry and make a {@dc 14} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. A character who saw through her previous lie has Advantage on this check. On a successful check, the sentry's attitude improves to {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}, and she stands down; she warns the characters about the gelatinous cube's impending arrival but doesn't let them past the barricades. On a failed check, the sentry commands the characters to leave at once or be destroyed.

entries.name: Fighting the Hobgoblins
entries: In combat, the sentry remains behind the barricades. If the characters breach either barricade, the sentry uses her next action to blow a war horn, alerting the other hobgoblins in the cave. She then retreats to the barrack ({@area area F4|0a6|x}), where she and the rest of the hobgoblins make their last stand.

entries.name: Spear Barricade
entries: A spear barricade is a bristly cube of interlocking spears. Each spear barricade has these rules.

entries.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: The barricade is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. A creature that moves through the barricade takes {@damage 1d6} Piercing damage.

entries.name: Provides Half Cover
entries: A creature behind the barricade has {@table Cover|XPHB|Half Cover}.

entries.name: Breaking the Barricade
entries: The barricade has AC 15, HP 4, and Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage. If reduced to 0 Hit Points, the barricade is destroyed.

entries.name: F2: Cube Route

entries: This smooth tunnel forms a rectangular circuit.

A hungry {@creature Gelatinous Cube|XMM} slowly loops counterclockwise through this part of the cave. It takes about 1 minute for it to complete a lap. The cube occasionally meanders down the eastern tunnel toward {@area cave D|073|x} and back again, but it never crosses the spear barricades (see the "{@area Spear Barricade|09f|x}" sidebar).

The cube is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures and fights them on detection. Clever characters might be able to lure the cube out of the cave through the entrance to area F1, shutting the door behind them.

entries.name: F3: Mess Hall
entries: The hobgoblins dine in this mess hall. They erected a pair of spear barricades (see the "{@area Spear Barricade|09f|x}" sidebar) to keep the gelatinous cube in area F2 out. The room contains nothing of value to the characters.

entries.name: F4: Barrack

entries: This chamber contains a dozen stiff-looking cots, but only four have seen recent use. A large iron strongbox sits against the east wall. A hobgoblin warrior, sword in hand, stands before it.

The surviving hobgoblins lodge in this once-full barrack. A lone {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM} fiercely defends what few valuables remain. He starts combat with the characters on sight and fights to the death.
If the hobgoblin sentry sounded the alarm in {@area area F1|09c|x}, the two {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM|Hobgoblin Warriors} from area F5 are also here, ready to intercept the characters.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest includes stolen goods: fine furs worth 75 GP, a pouch containing 20 GP, and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: F5: Training Hall

entries: This training hall holds bare weapon racks and four straw-stuffed targets painted with bullseyes.
Two hobgoblin archers fire at the targets.

Unless they were called elsewhere, two {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM|Hobgoblin Warriors} train in this hall, which was stripped of its weapons during a raid. The hobgoblins are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward intruders and fight them on sight.

entries.name: G: Shunned Caves
entries: An owlbear—a frightening cross between a bear and a giant owl—lurks in this cave. Most other denizens of the valley give the cave a wide berth.

This cave is connected to {@area cave K|0f6|x}, a hotbed of activity for the Cult of Chaos, whose members venerate powers of disorder and destruction. The cult mainly operates in the adjacent cave, but as its ranks swell, cultists increasingly frequent this one. The owlbear is unaware of the cultists' presence.

You can add monsters, such as {@creature Zombie|XMM|Zombies}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can reduce the number of {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists} or {@creature Gray Ooze Glob|HotB|Gray Ooze Globs} to make it easier and shorter.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: This cave is connected to {@area cave K|0f6|x} via the stairs south of {@area area G6|0b9|x} (see {@adventure map G|HotB|1|Map G: Shunned Caves (DM's Version) View Without Tokens}). If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:
The stench of rot and wet stone issues from this natural cave. An unsettling screech and the sound of thick feathers ruffling echo within.
The owlbear is moving restlessly in its den ({@area area G5|0b6|x}).

entries.name: Shunned Cave Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 15 feet high.

items.name: Door
items.entry: The stone door to {@area area G6|0b9|x} is ajar.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The eastern half of this cave ({@area areas G1|0b0|x}–{@area G5|0b6|x}) has naturally formed spaces with wet walls and damp dirt floors. The western half of the cave ({@area areas G6|0b9|x}–{@area G7|0bc|x}) has walls made of cut stone blocks and floors made of cracked tiles.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: Unless noted otherwise, the cave is unlit. Its denizens use {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Shunned Cave Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map G.

entries.name: G1: Entrance
entries: Gnawed bones litter the ground near the cave mouth, and the stench of blood hangs in the air. The bones belong to the owlbear's victims, including animals, explorers, and other monsters. The bones bear indentations from the owlbear's toothed beak.

entries.name: G2: Shallow Pool

entries: Moisture drips from the ceiling of this damp cave, forming a shallow pool. Something glitters in the murky water.

Two {@creature Gray Ooze Glob|HotB|Gray Ooze Globs} lurk in the pool, which is 2 feet deep and {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} oozes fight any creature that comes within 5 feet of the water.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The pool contains a jewel-encrusted goblet (worth 100 GP) and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: G3: Tight Passage
entries: A narrow crack spans the cave wall here. The opening is only big enough for a Medium or smaller creature to fit through. Inside, the mangled corpse of a human explorer slumps against a stalagmite.
The owlbear in {@area area G5|0b6|x} can't fit through the crack. If a character seeks refuge here, the owlbear loses interest and returns to its den.

entries.name: G4: Smelly Refuse
entries: This cave contains heaps of food scraps, rotting carcasses, and a scattering of halfling-size bird pellets composed of fur and regurgitated bones.

entries.name: G5: Owlbear Den

entries: A monstrous creature with a thick, shaggy hide and a feathered, owllike head paces aggressively in this den between nests formed from damp leaves and bloodstained branches.
A territorial {@creature Owlbear|XMM} lairs in this den. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} owlbear fights all other creatures on sight.

entries.name: Ledge
entries: At the chamber's south end, a ledge 10 feet above the floor marks the entrance to a tunnel to areas G6 and {@area G7|0bc|x}. To climb the cave's slippery walls to reach the ledge, a character must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. The owlbear doesn't pursue characters beyond the ledge.

entries.name: G6: Cult Barrack

entries: These cult quarters contain beds, a table, and several chairs. Tapestries on the walls depict evil creatures and obscene rituals. Four humans in hooded red robes recline on the beds.

Torches in wall sconces fill this room with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}. Four {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists} relax in these quarters for the Cult of Chaos. They are nonchalantly discussing the finer points of mayhem, torture, and other cruelties.

The cultists are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward intruders not garbed in their cult's attire and eagerly inflict violence on nonbelievers. As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to de-escalate the situation and make one of the following ability checks (with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} if the character is dressed like a member of the Cult of Chaos). Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character deceives the cultists with a lie, such as pretending to be a fellow cultist or an aspiring member.
{@b {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}).} The character convinces the cultists that it is in both parties' interests not to fight.
On a successful check, the cultists' attitudes improve to {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}. Otherwise, the cultists fight.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Footlockers under four of the beds contain the cultists' belongings. Each contains 5 GP, a few worthless personal effects, and a {@item Cultist's Robe|HotB}, which the characters can also take from cultists defeated here.

entries.name: G7: Crypt

entries: Damp stairs descend to this musty crypt. A closed stone sarcophagus sits at the north end.

A {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Wight Lifedrinker|HotB} rests in the sarcophagus. The monster was once a cult leader who was so wicked in life that when he died, he rose as a cruel undead warrior. As an action, a character can pry open the lid of the sarcophagus, at which point the wight springs forth and fights.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The sarcophagus holds one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: H: Bugbear Lair
entries: This cave recently came under the control of three belligerent bugbears and the goblin stooges they've cowed into their service. The bugbears are plotting an assault on the Keep on the Borderlands. They dream of destroying the keep and looting its riches.
You can add another {@creature Bugbear Warrior|XMM} to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can remove one or more of them to make it easier and shorter.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: This cave is connected to {@area cave I|0d3|x} via the the secret door in {@area area H5|0cd|x} (see {@adventure map H|HotB|1|Map H: Bugbear Lair (DM's Version) View Without Tokens}). If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:
A tunnel of rough stone is tucked behind several bushes. Within, you hear two deep voices in a heated argument. The conversation is unintelligible at this range.
The voices belong to a pair of bugbears quarreling in the war room ({@area area H2|0c5|x}).

entries.name: Bugbear Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 10 feet high.

items.name: Doors and Secret Doors
items.entry: The doors in this cave are made of sturdy wood planks. The secret door in {@area area H5|0cd|x} blends in with the surrounding wall. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to scan that area for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The walls are made of rough-hewn stone in some places and neat-fitting stone blocks in others. Stone tiles cover the floor.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Bugbear Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map H.

entries.name: H1: Entrance
entries: Just inside the cave, a tunnel branches east and west.

entries.name: H2: War Room
entries: The door to this makeshift war room is ajar, allowing the characters to hear two gruff voices bickering inside. When the characters enter or peek inside, read or paraphrase the following text:
This room contains an old table and four upright logs. A poorly drawn map of the Borderlands covers the table. Two tall, furry goblinoids hunch over the map, arguing with each other.

Two {@creature Bugbear Warrior|XMM|Bugbear Warriors} squabble about how best to infiltrate the keep. One asserts that a stealthy approach would be best, while the other insists on a direct assault aided by a {@area local ogre mercenary|08f|x} (see {@area cave E|087|x}). The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} bugbears fight the characters on sight and can't be bargained with.

entries.name: H3: Stairway

entries: Stairs ascend north. At the top of the stairs is a heavy log the width of the stairway. Two goblins stand guard on a landing halfway up the stairs.
These two {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM|Goblin Warriors} are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters. When the goblins detect an intruder to the south, roll Initiative.
On the goblins' turn, they attempt to scramble up the stairs and activate the rolling log trap (detailed below). The goblins then fight the characters.

entries.name: Rolling Log Trap
entries: This 10-foot-long log rolls down an incline, flattening creatures in its path.

As an action, a creature within 5 feet of the stationary log can push it down the stairs. The log tumbles down the incline in a straight line. Each creature in the log's path must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d6} Bludgeoning damage and has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.

entries.name: H4: Trophy Room

entries: The stuffed heads of deer, wolves, and other beasts are mounted on the walls of this room, as are a few humanoid heads with ghastly expressions. Skulls are piled in the northwest corner.
Among the trophies are a number of empty mounts equal to the characters in the party—a grim omen of what could happen if they're defeated in this cave.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The skulls hide a purse containing 10 GP.

entries.name: H5: Hall

entries: Musty animal furs serve as beds in this stark hall, where a furry brute berates two smaller, squeaky-voiced goblin subordinates.

A {@creature Bugbear Warrior|XMM}—the self-proclaimed boss of the cave—scolds two {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM|Goblin Warriors} for sleeping on the job. When they notice the characters, the bugbear commands the goblins to fight and joins them in battle. The bugbear is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the party, while the goblins are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}.

entries.name: Swaying the Goblins
entries: These fickle goblins, Gargle and Yams, were recently recruited and don't like being yelled at.

As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to shake the goblins' loyalty and make one of the following checks (with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} if the party already defeated the bugbear). Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character tricks the goblins into believing the party now commands the cave.
{@b {@dc 11} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB}).} The character scares the goblins into fearing for their lives.
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}).} The character convinces the goblins the party means them no harm.

On a successful check, the goblins' attitudes improve to {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}. In exchange for a bribe of at least 2 GP, the goblins also help the characters defeat any remaining bugbears in the cave and tell the characters about the secret door in this area, though the goblins don't know what lies on the other side.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Scattered among the furs on the floor are 25 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: H6: Boss's Chamber
entries: A heap of thick animal furs forms a soft bed in this room, where the bugbear boss in area H5 sleeps.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Stashed in the furs are 25 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: I: Minotaur Lair
entries: A bloodthirsty minotaur rules this cave. A servant of {@book Baphomet|XDMG|5|Layer 600: The Endless Maze}—a demon lord who endorses bloodshed and cruelty—the minotaur feasts on adventurers and monsters alike. It stalks its lair, huffing in bestial rage.
The minotaur's only companions are the vermin that scavenge its grisly leftovers. Deprived of recent visitors to its cave, the minotaur hungers for new playthings to hunt.

You can add monsters to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult. One or more {@creature Bandit|XMM|Bandits} might be here searching for hidden treasure. Conversely, you can reduce the number of {@creature Stirge|XMM|Stirges} to make the scenario easier and shorter.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: This cave is connected to {@area cave H|0bf|x} via the secret door in {@area area I3|0dd|x} (see {@adventure map I|HotB|1|Map I: Minotaur Lair (DM's Version) View Without Tokens}). If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:
The entrance to this cave is a gaping maw of crumbling gray bricks. A low bellow rumbles within, causing dirt to trickle from the roof of the cave mouth.

entries.name: Minotaur Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 15 feet high.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The cave walls are made of hard-packed dirt reinforced with crumbling pillars and brickwork. Crushed bones lie scattered about the dirt floor.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

items.name: Secret Doors
items.entry: The secret doors in {@area areas I3|0dd|x} and {@area I4|0e0|x} blend in with their surroundings. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character in either of those areas can make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to scan the area for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check.

entries.name: Minotaur Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map I.

entries.name: I1: Entrance

entries: Bones litter the furrowed dirt around the cave mouth.
Pressed into the dirt are the broken bones of the minotaur's past victims—unlucky goblins, kobolds, and explorers who stumbled on the monster's lair.

entries.name: Hoof Tracks
entries: A character who inspects the area and succeeds on a {@dc 11} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check notices hoof tracks left by a hulking, bipedal creature. The tracks lead west.

entries.name: I2: Stirge Lair

entries: The floor of this bloodstained cavern is strewn with small animal bones and the shriveled-up carcasses of cave-dwelling bats and rodents. A dim orange glow emanates from the north.

Three {@creature Stirge|XMM|Stirges} hang asleep from the ceiling. These flying pests subsist on a diet of fresh blood. The stirges avoid the minotaur, but they are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures.

{@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} or any noise louder than a whisper wakes the stirges, which then start combat. The light from the fire beetles in area I3 is visible from here but is too dim to awaken the stirges. In combat, the stirges gorge themselves until they've drunk the characters dry.

entries.name: I3: Fire Beetle Sanctuary

entries: Old bricks reinforce the walls of this dirt cave. The cave contains two beetles, each as big as a dog and glowing with warm orange light. The beetles search the dirt floor for grubs.

Two {@creature Giant Fire Beetle|XMM|Giant Fire Beetles} scrape up the dirt in search of tasty morsels. The beetles keep a safe distance from the minotaur and defend themselves if necessary. They are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters.

entries.name: Taming the Beetles
entries: As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can make a {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}) check to tame a fire beetle. A character who waves a light source at the beetle has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on this check. On a successful check, the beetle becomes {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} toward the character and follows them throughout this cave, warmly illuminating their surroundings. While accompanied in this way, the character has Advantage on checks to notice secret doors. The beetles don't leave cave I.

entries.name: I4: Minotaur Maze
