entries: Thick columns hewn from brick and dirt form tunnels in this labyrinthine cave. A jumble of overlapping hoofprints cover the blood-speckled dirt floor, and scratches mar the walls.

A {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Minotaur of Baphomet|XMM} prowls amid the columns, stamping its hooves in the dirt and sharpening its horns on the walls. The minotaur charges the characters on sight and fights to the death. No amount of pleading, persuasion, or deceit can slake its bloodlust.

entries.name: I5: Secret Spoils

entries: A wooden chest sits on the floor of this chamber.
The chest was placed here by bandits who used this cave as a hideout until the minotaur arrived and slew them all.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest contains 120 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: J: Gnoll Lair
entries: Evil gnolls—tall, shaggy fiends with hyenoid heads—have turned this abandoned shrine into their lair. The gnolls heard rumors that treasure is hidden somewhere in this cave, but they've been unable to find it due to an illusion placed by a long-dead mage. Vicious and hot-tempered, the gnolls have little patience for those who interrupt their search.

You can add monsters to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult. One or more {@creature Bugbear Warrior|XMM|Bugbear Warriors} might have formed a tenuous alliance with the gnolls. Conversely, you can reduce the number of {@creature Gnoll Warrior|XMM|Gnoll Warriors} to make the scenario easier and shorter.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
All is quiet outside the yawning mouth of this natural cave, at the back of which you can just make out a pair of featureless stone doors.

entries.name: Gnoll Lair Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 10 feet high.

items.name: Doors
items.entry: The doors to {@area area J2|0ec|x} are made of stone.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: Past its entrance, the cave's natural rock gives way to crumbling stone blocks and flagstone tiles. Its walls are decorated with painted motifs of grinning demons and marching skeletons.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

entries.name: Gnoll Lair Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map J.

entries.name: J1: Entrance

entries: Set into the west wall of this natural cavern is a stone double door that is partly open. Bestial, high-pitched laughter echoes within.
The gnolls rigged the door with a makeshift alarm.

items.name: Door Alarm
items.entry: This simple alarm consists of armor scraps and rusty weapons balanced atop the partly open double door. Moving either door triggers the trap, the rules for which are as follows:

items.name: Avoiding the Trap
items.entry: A Medium or smaller creature can slip through the gap between the doors with a successful {@dc 13} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check; failing this check triggers the trap.

items.name: Detect and Disable
items.entry: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can examine the door and make a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, detecting the trap on a successful check. Once detected, the trap can be disabled by a character who takes the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check; failing this check triggers the trap.

items.name: Triggering the Trap
items.entry: If the door is moved, the scraps clatter to the ground. The noise alerts all the gnolls in the cave, who cackle as they rush to dispatch intruders.

entries.name: J2: Junk Pile

entries: The center of this chamber's floor is piled with loose junk—broken ceremonial implements, rusty candlestick holders, and rotten rags.
The gnolls piled objects here to sift through later.

items.name: DM Tip!
items.entry: If you increased this cave's difficulty, one or more {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Bugbear Warrior|XMM|Bugbear Warriors} might be here rummaging through the junk.

entries.name: J3: Old Chapel

entries: This forlorn chapel is unfurnished, though a slightly depressed section of floor near the southeast wall suggests an altar or some other heavy object once rested there.
Two tall warriors with mangy hides and hocked knees move about the chamber slowly, their hyena-like heads sniffing its walls.

Two {@creature Gnoll Warrior|XMM|Gnoll Warriors} scour this chamber for secret doors. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} gnolls lunge at intruders in a frenzy. Combat in this chamber draws the attention of the gnolls in area J4, which quickly join the fray.

If the characters defeat all but one gnoll, the last of them surrenders. As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to cow the gnoll into submission and make a {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the gnoll's attitude improves to {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}, and the gnoll reveals that its pack was searching for "a prize hidden in the mouth of a laughing fiend." On a failed check, the gnoll flees without divulging any information.

entries.name: J4: Shrine of the Laughing Devil

entries: A stone dais spans much of the south wall of this eerie shrine. Above the dais, a mosaic of black and red tiles depicts the face of a laughing devil whose forked tongue curls down to the dais.

Unless drawn elsewhere, two {@creature Gnoll Warrior|XMM|Gnoll Warriors} pace about this chamber, frustrated in their fruitless search for treasure. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} gnolls behave similarly to the pair in area J3; combat in this chamber draws those gnolls here.

entries.name: Illusory Wall
entries: The laughing devil face is an illusory wall; it looks real to the eye but has no substance. A creature that touches the illusory wall discovers its true nature and can pass right through it.

As a {@action Study|XPHB} action, a character can make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check to discern the wall's true nature. On a successful check, the character recognizes the wall is a magical illusion.

entries.name: J5: Hidden Crypt

entries: The devil's face ripples to reveal a dusty crypt. Ancient bones and rubble litter the tiled floor. An austere sarcophagus stands in each corner, and an ornate chest rests in the center of the room.

Long ago, an evil mage reanimated the corpses of four explorers and commanded them to guard this crypt's treasure for all eternity. Entombed here are four {@creature Zombie|XMM|Zombies}, one in each sarcophagus.

If the characters touch any of the sarcophagi or the chest, the {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Zombie|XMM|zombies} push the lids off their containers and start combat, seeking to rend intruders limb from limb.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Among the debris is the skeleton of a human thief. The thief's purse contains 15 GP and a large gemstone (worth 100 GP).
The chest is unlocked. It contains one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: K: Shrine of Evil Chaos
entries: The Cult of Chaos performs evil rites in this cave, subtly drawing monsters to inhabit the Caves of Chaos and bring strife to the Borderlands. The current cult leader is Ivlis, the keep's former priest. Her cruel assistant, Narthus, is always here, and other cultists dwell close by (see {@area cave G|0ab|x}). Undead guardians defend the shrine and the Chaos Bell—the source of the cult's foul magic—at the shrine's heart.

You can add monsters, such as {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can reduce the number of {@creature Skeleton|XMM|Skeletons} or {@creature Zombie|XMM|Zombies} to make the scenario easier and shorter.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: This cave is connected to {@area cave G|0ab|x} via the stairs east of {@area area K5|100|x} (see {@adventure map K|HotB|1|Map K: Shrine Of Evil Chaos (DM's Version) View Without Tokens}). If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:
A foul draft issues from this cave. Red strata intertwine with bulging black veins running through the hewn rock. A sinister crimson light dances deep in the cave.
The stench issues from the rotting ogre in {@area area K2|0fc|x}.

entries.name: Shrine Features
entries: The cave has the following features:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: The cave's ceilings are 20 feet high.

items.name: Doors and Secret Doors
items.entry: Doors throughout this cave are made of heavy stone. The secret doors to {@area area K8|108|x} blend in with their surroundings but are obvious from inside area K8. As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check to examine the wall for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check.

items.name: Environment
items.entry: The cave instills a sense of unease in its visitors.

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: Unless otherwise noted, {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} from red-flamed wall sconces fills the cave's areas.

entries.name: Shrine Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map K.

images.title: Map K: Shrine Of Evil Chaos (DM's Version)

entries.name: K1: Entrance
entries: Shadows shroud this foreboding entrance.

entries.name: K2: Guarded Hallway

entries: The stench of death fills this hallway. Flies buzz around a groaning, slack-jawed giant backlit by red-flamed wall sconces.
An {@creature Ogre Zombie|XMM} conscripted by the cultists to guard their nefarious acts stands watch here, but the undead brute is easily fooled.

The ogre zombie lets members of the Cult of Chaos pass unscathed, but it is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward entrants not garbed in the cult's attire and pummels them on sight. The creature is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward anyone wearing a {@item Cultist's Robe|HotB}.

entries.name: K3: Chapel of Evil Chaos
entries: Four pillars support the domed roof of this empty chapel, where cultists conduct foul ceremonies.

items.name: DM Tip!
items.entry: If you increased this cave's difficulty, two or more {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists} might be in the midst of an unholy ceremony here.

entries.name: K4: Undead Barrack
entries: Four {@creature Zombie|XMM|Zombies} shamble restlessly in this bare chamber. They fight any non-Undead not garbed in the cult's attire but are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward anyone wearing a {@item Cultist's Robe|HotB}.

entries.name: K5: Altar of Evil Chaos

entries: Violet draperies curtain this chamber. Three stone altars stand before a dais topped with five chairs: four rickety seats made of bone flanking a high-backed throne. An ominous, black iron bell hangs from a stand near the middle of the room.
Piles of humanoid bones are arranged neatly near the north wall. A cultist flecks the bones with blood while intoning a demonic chant.

{@creature Narthus|HotB} chants evil litanies in this impious chamber. He is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters, even if they're garbed in cult attire; Narthus screens every new cultist and knows his fellow cult members well.

If the characters interrupt the ritual, Narthus decries them as blasphemers and starts combat. On his turn, Narthus tries to ring the Chaos Bell, causing the bones to animate (see the "Chaos Bell" section).

entries.name: Chaos Bell
entries: Hanging from the stand is the Chaos Bell, a profane relic whose toll can wake the dead.

As a Bonus Action, a creature within 5 feet of the Chaos Bell can ring it, causing the bone piles to knit together and arise as four Hostile {@creature Skeleton|XMM|Skeletons}. The tolling bell also summons the {@creature Zombie|XMM|Zombies} in {@area area K4|0ff|x} to the fray. The skeletons and zombies obey Narthus's commands.

The Chaos Bell is all but indestructible. To destroy the bell and end its magic, the characters must submerge it in the {@area sacred spring|1fb|x} (see the "{@adventure Wilderness|HotB|3}" section). If a character removes the bell from its stand, give that player the Chaos Bell.

entries.name: K6: Visitor's Chamber
entries: This room has comfortable chairs and a low table. Cult leaders interview potential new recruits here.

entries.name: K7: Cult Leader's Room

entries: This opulent chamber contains a large bed, desk, and wardrobe. A ghastly demon head is mounted on the wall. Kneeling before the demon is a human woman wearing bloodred robes and a spidery headdress.

{@creature Ivlis|HotB}, leader of the Cult of Chaos, lives here. Each day, she pays tribute to the severed demon head mounted on the wall, which she talks to when no one's around. Ivlis is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters.

If confronted, Ivlis first tries to tempt the party with promises of untold riches and power, claiming all things are possible through the Cult of Chaos. She urges the characters to submit to the cult and become Undead. If they refuse, she fights.

entries.name: Fighting Ivlis
entries: In combat, the sneering cult leader fights arrogantly and doesn't hold back. If reduced to 15 Hit Points or fewer, however, she tries to flee the cave through area K8 via the secret door. If Ivlis escapes, she attempts to revive the cult elsewhere.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The demon head pivots to reveal a nook with 100 GP, a large red garnet (worth 100 GP), and two magic items; roll twice on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the items.

entries.name: K8: Secret "Treasure"
entries: This hidden room contains only a black iron chest. When a creature moves within 5 feet of the chest, it springs opens and spills 300 GP across the floor.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The coins are cheap counterfeits intended to slow greedy pursuers. A cursory examination of the coins reveals them as fakes.

data.name: Keep on the Borderlands
entries: Rising from rugged crags amid a harsh countryside, the Keep on the Borderlands is a bastion of peace amid an otherwise brutal wilderness. The keep's stalwart defenders protect their community from the forces of chaos that would revel in its fall.

entries.name: DM Secret
entries: This is for the Dungeon Master's eyes only. Unless text appears in a read-aloud box (like the one below), don't read it to the players.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: The Keep on the Borderlands Map displays all the locations characters can visit in the keep. Share this map with your players.
To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

You ascend a winding road through a forested and mountainous country. Ahead, atop a sheer-walled stone plateau, looms a great and stoic keep. Armed sentries along the outer wall peer down at you, ready to welcome new heroes or repel would-be invaders.
Two armed guards stand at the front gate. They hail you and motion for you to approach.

The player characters start just outside the keep. The first time they arrive at the keep, the characters must proceed to the {@area outer gatehouse|117|x} (detailed later in this chapter), which functions as a tutorial with helpful sidebars. You can skip this location for subsequent visits to the keep unless the player characters want to return to it.

After the characters visit the gatehouse or whenever they return to the keep, have the players choose a location shown on the map. The Keep Locations table summarizes noteworthy sites within the keep in the order they appear. Each location provides approximately 30–60 minutes of gameplay, depending on the nature of the characters' visit.
Once the player characters choose a location, go to that location and review its "What You Need to Play" section.

entries.caption: Keep Locations
rows: Guards vet entrants and keep watch at this gate.
Livestock and steeds are stabled and groomed here.
These modest apartments house long-term residents.
A blacksmith crafts metalwork goods here.
This messy, halfling-owned shop specializes in gear.
This trading post sells armor and weapons.
The keep's citizens store their valuables at this bank.
Travelers can rent rooms at this cozy inn.
Patrons flock to this rowdy tavern for food and drink.
Merchants and artisans assemble in this guildhall.
Priests offer guidance and healing in this house of worship.
This fortification is the keep's last line of defense.
The keep's guards live and train in this enclosed court.
The castellan governs the keep from this stronghold.

entries.name: Exploring the Keep
entries: The player characters can visit any location in the keep, meeting and interacting with the citizens who reside there. Each keep location employs one or more NPCs, typically representing the most important person at a location, such as an establishment's owner or highest ranking representative.

The map of the keep isn't to scale, but you can use it to track the characters' current whereabouts. If this is your first time as Dungeon Master, ask your players to keep the party together; it's easier if the player characters visit each location as a group.

entries.name: Location Descriptions
entries: Each description of a keep location has the following sections:

items.name: Features
items.entry: This section details noteworthy features about the location.

items.name: NPCs
items.entry: Each keep location contains one or more NPCs, each reflected by a digital NPC Card nested within the section.

items.name: Services
items.entry: Services offered at the location, such as goods for sale or rooms for rent, appear here. If a player character pays for a good or service, collect Gold Pieces equal to its cost from that player.

items.name: Quest
items.entry: This section contains a quest unique to the location. Most take place in the keep, though some encourage the characters to venture beyond its walls. Each quest can be completed only once.

entries.name: Social Interaction
entries: The keep offers ample opportunities for characters to socialize with its inhabitants. All NPCs in the keep are initially {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters. For more about {@variantrule Attitude|XPHB|NPC attitudes}, see the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}.

entries.name: Combat
entries: Combat is prohibited in the keep. If you need game statistics for an NPC, reference the recommended stat block listed on their NPC Card.

At your discretion, characters who antagonize peaceful members of the keep might attract the attention of the soldiers of the keep, of whom there are many (use the {@creature Guard|XMM} stat block). Those who refuse to keep the peace might be arrested and detained for a few days, fined up to 50 GP, or ousted from the keep until they can behave.
The following stat blocks are used in this section:

entries.name: Resting
entries: Unlike in the other two adventure settings, the keep is a safe place to rest and resupply. The characters can freely take {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB|Long Rests} in the keep. For more on {@book resting|XPHB|1|Resting}, see the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}.

entries.name: Leaving the Keep
entries: The player characters can leave the Keep on the Borderlands whenever they choose. As they accumulate treasure and advance in level, the party might return to spend their hard-earned wealth, rest, or follow up on previously undertaken quests.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: Though there are quests to complete in the Keep on the Borderlands, the characters don't gain levels in this section. Each quest offers its own reward, usually in the form of gold or favors.

entries.name: 1: Outer Gatehouse
entries: This gatehouse is the first stop for those seeking to enter the Keep on the Borderlands. The guards here greet outsiders, watch for potential threats, and permit entrance to citizens and peaceful visitors.

entries.name: Summary
entries: The beginning of each location summarizes its function in the keep and the NPCs who can be found at it. Don't read this aloud.
When the characters arrive at the outer gatehouse, read the following boxed text aloud:

Two stone towers flank an archway that leads into the keep. A sturdy-looking gatehouse spans the archway and connects the towers. A wooden drawbridge allows passage over a steep ditch surrounding the keep. The bridge is currently drawn shut.
Two guards stand before the raised bridge. As you approach, one of the guards shouts, "Hail! Do you bring peace or trouble?"

entries.name: Boxed Text
entries: Text that appears in a box like the one in this section is meant to be read aloud or paraphrased for the players when their characters first arrive at a location or under a specific circumstance, as described in the text.

The guards are Bartho and Gala. The characters must respond to the guards and say whether they mean well or ill. After confirming the characters are well-meaning adventurers, Bartho and Gala call for the drawbridge to be lowered, then welcome the party to the keep.

entries.name: Bartho
entries: {@i Human Gate Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard|XMM}

entries: This gullible recruit spends more time dreaming than patrolling.

items.name: Distractable
items.entry: Bartho is easily distracted from his post because he'd rather be doing anything else.

items.name: Sleepy
items.entry: Bartho likes to catch a few winks during the night shift.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "If you can't afford a bed at the inn, Cornflower will let you sleep in the barn. The hay's real comfy." (True})
{@i "Minotaurs aren't real. They're just a myth told to scare little children from wandering into caves." (False})

entries.name: Gala
entries: {@i Human Gate Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard|XMM}

entries: Though she's memorized all the keep's laws, this guard still has much to learn.

items.name: By the Books
items.entry: Gala clings to the keep's laws—and often recites them aloud—whenever she must make a decision.

items.name: Naive
items.entry: Gala believes that life is fair, people mostly tell the truth, and good always prevails.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "I've heard the captain of the guard, Andrella, plans to retire soon." (False})
{@i "The keep's coat of arms honors its cavalry, thirty riders strong. I hope to become one." (True})

entries.name: Social Interaction
entries: Player characters can meet many different people throughout the keep. As DM, you assume the roles of these nonplayer characters, whom you can embody through either active or descriptive roleplaying (detailed below). Players also use one or both of these approaches to roleplay their characters.
Regardless of the approach you prefer, use each nonplayer character's NPC Card to determine how they react to the character's words and actions.

items.name: Active Roleplaying
items.entry: In active roleplaying, you speak with a character's voice and might echo their body language, like an actor taking on a role. You still need to describe things that can't reasonably be acted out.

entries: An active approach to roleplaying Bartho, an inexperienced guard prone to daydreaming, might involve you pretending to yawn mid-sentence or getting distracted by a butterfly. Perhaps he confides with the characters that he'd rather be doing something else.

items.name: Descriptive Roleplaying
items.entry: In descriptive roleplaying, you draw on your mental image of the character, saying what the character does and how they do it.

entries: A descriptive approach to roleplaying Gala, a straitlaced guard who hopes to ascend in rank, might involve you describing her dutiful posture or no-nonsense expression. You might tell the players that she cautions the characters not to cause trouble as they enter the keep.

entries.name: Gatehouse Features
entries: The gatehouse has the following features:

items.name: Drawbridge
items.entry: The keep's first line of defense is a steep ditch, 10 feet wide and 10 feet deep, in front of the fortress. The only sure means to cross the dry moat is the drawbridge at this gatehouse.

items.name: Gate
items.entry: The stone arch behind the drawbridge contains an iron portcullis and large oak doors.

items.name: Towers
items.entry: Stairs inside each square, 30-foot-tall tower connect the ground floor to the roof. Arrow slits in the tower walls and roof battlements help archers defend the keep.

entries.name: Features
entries: Some features about a location help you set the mood or describe aspects of the location, while others detail important gameplay information, like the depth of the keep's moat (in case a creature falls into it).

entries.name: Gatehouse Services
entries: The gatehouse offers the following services:

items.name: Lower the Drawbridge
items.entry: The drawbridge usually remains raised night and day. To lower or raise the bridge, wheels in both towers must be turned to release or tighten the drawbridge's chains. The portcullis operates in a similar manner.

entries.name: Services
entries: Each location offers unique services. Shops typically offer goods for sale, which might be associated with a handout, while other locations offer more abstract benefits. An NPC at the location can summarize its services to the characters.

items.name: Orientation
items.entry: The gate guards, Bartho and Gala, can describe and give directions to any location in the keep. They can also tailor recommendations to a traveler's needs. For example, if a character wants to purchase weapons or armor, the guards point them to the trader's shop ({@area area 6|155|x}).

entries.name: Quest: Entry Screening
entries: Once the drawbridge is lowered, Bartho and Gala introduce themselves and encourage the characters to lend their services to the keep.

entries.name: Exploration and Movement
entries: Exploration is open-ended; the players don't take turns moving around the keep the way they do in combat. Instead, players simply say where they want their characters to go. None of the locations within the keep has or requires its own map; as DM, you help the players visualize these places through your descriptions.
Read the following boxed text aloud:

"The keep has plenty of need for hearty adventurers like you," Gala says. "If you want to make a name for yourselves in this community and earn the castellan's respect, you should visit locations within the keep and offer your aid."
"Residents usually pay for a job well done," Bartho adds casually.

Before they venture into the Borderlands, the characters can report to the fortress ({@area area 14|1a3|x}) for more information on how they can further the interests of the castellan and his advisers.

entries.name: Quest
entries: Every location in the keep offers a quest: a heroic task or odd job intended for the party. The characters don't have to complete a quest at a location to benefit from its services. Unless stated otherwise, the characters can decline a quest; they can always return to complete it at a later time. Each quest's reward is stated at the end of its section.

entries.name: Bartho's Reward
entries: The guards here have orders to help out around the keep between shifts, but Bartho claims he must rest instead to stay sharp when he's on duty. He pulls the characters aside and asks them to complete quests around the keep for a small reward.
When the characters return to the outer gatehouse after completing at least three quests around the keep, Bartho thanks them and gives each character 5 GP.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Rewards within the keep usually come in the form of Gold Pieces (GP). Whenever a player character finds gold, give that player Gold Pieces equal to the listed value, which is tracked on their character sheet. Encourage players to split their treasure as evenly as possible.

entries.name: 2: Barn
entries: This barn shelters the keep's livestock. It also serves merchants and travelers who need a place to stable their mounts while visiting the keep. Animals housed at the barn receive a box stall or pen, food, and grooming.
When the characters arrive at the barn, read the following boxed text aloud:

Animals snuffle, cluck, oink, and moo inside the stalls of this spacious barn, which smells of leather and manure. A freckled halfling woman uses a pitchfork to unload hay from a nearby wagon into an empty stall. She wipes the sweat from her brow and extends a hearty greeting.
The halfling is Cornflower, the barn hand.

entries.name: Cornflower
entries: {@i Halfling Barn Hand}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: This spunky stable hand isn't afraid to get her hands dirty.

items.name: Animal Lover
items.entry: Cornflower's best friends are all barn animals.

items.name: Idiomatic
items.entry: Cornflower likes to use animal idioms, such as "busy bee," "chicken out," and "hold your horses."

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Did you know animals have all sorts of special glands? Giant fire beetles are like big glowing cave lanterns! Isn't nature amazing?" (True})
{@i "Careful if you go trekking into the wilderness. The tamaracks are overrun with giant spiders." (True})

entries.name: Barn Features
entries: The barn has the following features:

items.name: Box Stalls
items.entry: The barn has roomy stalls for up to six Large mounts.

items.name: Livestock Pens
items.entry: Cows, chickens, pigs, and other barn animals occupy several livestock pens.

items.name: Loft
items.entry: Golden piles of hay are stored in a loft above the animal enclosures.

items.name: Trough
items.entry: Stabled animals drink water from a common trough along the stalls.

entries.name: Barn Services
entries: The barn offers the following services:

items.name: Chores
items.entry: Once per day, the characters can assist Cornflower with chores around the barn, such as collecting freshly laid eggs, feeding and grooming animals, and milking cows and goats. In exchange for their help, Cornflower pays them 1 GP each.

items.name: Dairy Products
items.entry: For 1 GP, Cornflower sells a pail's worth of milk or a slab of freshly churned goat butter (customer's choice).

items.name: Hit the Hay
items.entry: Cornflower sympathizes with travelers who can't afford to stay at the inn ({@area area 8|16a|x}). She lets them sleep in the loft for free.

entries.name: Quest: Billy Goat Wranglin'
entries: After introducing herself and explaining the barn's services, Cornflower confesses she could use the characters' help. Read the following text aloud:

"Last night, I accidentally left the goat pen unlocked—and this mornin', all the goats were gone! I'm sure they're still within the keep, but I need to tend to the other animals here and make sure no others get loose. Would you track down the missin' goats and return them to the barn?"
Cornflower offers the characters 1 GP for every goat they bring back. The number of missing goats equals the number of player characters.

entries.name: Finding the Goats
entries: The goats are scattered throughout the keep. Roll {@dice 1d12} for each missing goat, rerolling duplicates. Keep these results secret. Each result corresponds to a numbered location on the {@adventure Keep on the Borderlands Map|HotB|2|Map: Keep on the Borderlands View Unlabeled Version} where a goat can be found. For example, on a 6, a goat is outside the trader's shop ({@area area 6|155|x}). To find the goat, the characters must go to that location, though they don't have to venture inside.
A character can narrow their search by making one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 10} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}).} The character follows hoofprints in the dirt.
{@b {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}).} The character asks passersby if they've seen a loose goat.
On a successful check, the character learns the location of one goat whose whereabouts the party doesn't already know.

entries.name: Returning the Goats
entries: When the characters arrive at a goat's location, they find it grazing outside the structure and can coax it back to the barn. When the characters return a goat to Cornflower, she pays them 1 GP as thanks.

entries.name: 3: Private Apartments
entries: Residents and long-term visitors rent apartments in this tenement building. The complex's most notable resident is also its landlord, a crotchety jeweler who invests in gemstones and other valuables.
When the characters arrive at the apartments, read the following boxed text aloud:
A wooden jeweler's sign hangs over an open door in the front of this two-story building. Inside, an old human man hunches over a table, peering at an emerald through a jeweler's loupe.
The jeweler, Lenk, puts down his loupe with a sigh and invites the characters in.

entries.name: Lenk
entries: {@i Human Jeweler}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: This elderly jeweler can identify and appraise any gemstone.

items.name: Faultfinder
items.entry: Lenk has a knack for spotting flaws, be they in things or people.

items.name: Pessimistic
items.entry: Lenk always sees the worst part of any situation.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Your money isn't safe at the bank. I hear a burglar broke in recently and stole every last coin." (Partially true; the burglar was unsuccessful})
{@i "Some stones hide things. The next time you're in an ancient dungeon or old cave, inspect the walls closely. You just might find a secret door." (True})

entries.name: Apartments Features
entries: The apartments have the following features:

items.name: Apartments
items.entry: Each two-story apartment is a section of the same large tenement building. The apartments have identical amenities: a stove, a small drawing room, a bedroom, and a storage area.

items.name: Rain Barrel
items.entry: A large barrel near the building holds clean water for washing dishes and clothes.

entries.name: Apartments Services
entries: The apartments offer the following services:

items.name: Buy Gems
items.entry: Lenk can buy gems the characters find in their adventures. Lenk exchanges gems at this location for their value in gold. All the gems in this adventure are worth 100 GP; this rate includes Lenk's appraisal fee.

items.name: Rent an Apartment
items.entry: Characters can rent an apartment for 100 GP per month.

entries.name: Quest: Breaking the Bank
entries: After detailing the services he offers, Lenk tells the characters he's exploring a new line of business. Read the following boxed text aloud:

"With reports of bandits along the trail and the occasional thief here in the keep, I plan to sell strongboxes to help citizens and travelers secure their valuables. I've received a few samples made by local crafters who hope to partner with me in this new venture, but I won't stake my reputation on shoddy handiwork.
"I need to determine which of the strongboxes are fit for sale, and you look like a capable lot. Care to test your mettle on some metal?"

If the characters agree, Lenk hands each of them a locked iron strongbox and instructs them to try to pilfer its contents however they please. Each strongbox contains a modest amount of gold. If a character can get into a strongbox, they can keep its contents, though Lenk doesn't reveal what's inside.

entries.name: Cracking the Strongboxes
entries: A character can make one attempt to open a strongbox through any of the following means:

items.name: Breaking the Strongbox
items.entry: Each strongbox is a Tiny object with AC 19, 5 HP, Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage, and Vulnerability to Cold damage. A character who reduces a strongbox to 0 Hit Points with a single attack or spell destroys the strongbox but not its contents.

entries: {@b Picking the Lock (A character who has Thieves' Tools}). A character that can use Thieves' Tools to pick the strongbox's lock, doing so with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check.

items.name: Prying Open the Lid
items.entry: A character can force open a strongbox's lid with a successful {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check.

entries: At the DM's discretion, other methods of opening a strongbox might exist.

entries.name: Reward
entries: Inside each strongbox is 5 GP. If the characters manage to penetrate all the strongboxes, Lenk grouses about the boxes' poor craftsmanship. If all the strongboxes thwart their attempts, Lenk pays each character 1 GP as a consolation and says there are nobler skills to master than thievery.

entries.name: 4: Smithy
entries: The smithy is where the keep's residents purchase metal goods and have them repaired.
When the characters arrive at the smithy, read the following boxed text aloud:

The stench of hot smoke and the sound of clanging metal fill this smithy. Lit by the orange glow of a forge, a dark-haired dwarf pounds a molten ingot at an anvil behind a low wooden counter. Sparks fly with every strike of her hammer.
The hard-working smith is Kalista.

entries.name: Kalista
entries: {@i Dwarf Blacksmith}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: The keep's taciturn, hardworking smith prefers to let her hammer do the talking.

items.name: Standoffish
items.entry: Kalista is curt toward people she doesn't know, especially adventurers.

items.name: Stern
items.entry: Kalista never cracks a smile.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Every now and then, adventurers return from the Caves of Chaos with magic weapons, but most of the time they don't come back at all." (True})
{@i "Mind your equipment around oozes. Their touch can corrode even the sturdiest of metals." (True})

entries.name: Smithy Features
entries: The smithy has the following features:

items.name: Forge
items.entry: The large forge behind the counter fills most of the smithy's lower floor. Water barrels and bellows flank the forge.

items.name: Mundane Goods
items.entry: A few stout posts support the upper floor. They bear hanging tools and everyday metal goods: cast-iron pots, horseshoes, and so on.

items.name: Private Rooms
items.entry: Two doors at the rear of the smithy lead to storerooms containing ingots and spare tools. A third door opens to a washbasin and spiral stairs that ascend to Kalista's quarters.

entries.name: Smithy Services
entries: The smithy offers the following service:

items.name: Leather Branding
items.entry: For 1 GP, Kalista can brand anything made of leather, such as Leather Armor or a Spellbook, with the keep's coat of arms.

entries: Kalista makes armaments but doesn't sell them. She forges them exclusively for the keep's armed forces.

entries.name: Quest: Tools of Destruction
entries: If a character asks to purchase armor or weapons, Kalista explains why she no longer sells those to outsiders. Read the following boxed text aloud:
"I used to sell arms and armor to would-be heroes like you. I had heard reports of foolhardy adventurers falling victim to brigands and monsters. I shrugged those stories off for a time.

"Last winter, the castellan's forces thwarted an assault on the keep. After the onslaught, I was sickened to learn that many of the attackers' weapons bore my maker's mark. By selling to outsiders, I had unwittingly armed our enemies. I vowed then never to forge another weapon for anyone but the keep's soldiers. I haven't since."
The keep's soldiers occasionally bring confiscated weapons to Kalista for destruction.

entries.name: Weapon Smelting
entries: Kalista recently received a cartload of battered and rusted weapons seized by the keep's defenders. She asks the characters to help melt them down.
The disarmament process takes 1 hour. To aid Kalista with it, the characters must succeed on the following ability checks in this order:
{@b {@dc 13} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}).} The character piles the weapons in the forge and undertakes the tough labor needed to properly melt them down.
{@b {@dc 13} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}).} The character carefully tips a crucible of molten metal into an ingot mold without spillage.

If at least one character succeeds on each check, the party completes the disarmament. The characters can retry failed checks, but if they accumulate three failures, Kalista dismisses them with a sigh, insisting she can handle the rest of the job herself.
If the characters successfully help Kalista destroy the weapons, she pays them each 5 GP.

entries.name: 5: Provisioner's Shop
entries: This cluttered shop provides supplies for travelers who venture into the wilderness.
When the characters arrive at the shop, read the following boxed text aloud:
Dusty rays of sunlight stream into this general store through small windows near the ceiling. Barrels, bottles, boxes, and other supplies crowd its shelves.
An affable halfling named Ruckus runs this shop.

entries.name: Ruckus
entries: {@i Halfling Shopkeeper}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: The owner of the provisioner's shop is small but has a big personality.

items.name: Loud
items.entry: Ruckus compensates for his short stature by shouting up to taller customers.

items.name: Everything Has a Place
items.entry: Despite the mess in his shop, Ruckus always knows exactly where to find just what he's looking for.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "I hear goblins throw wild parties." (Oh Yeah}!)
{@i "Lenk the jeweler gives a fair price for gems and precious stones. He lives in the private apartments." (True})

entries.name: Shop Features
entries: The shop has the following features:

items.name: Brimming with Supplies
items.entry: Everyday supplies fill the shop's packed interior. Shelves, crates, chests, and cabinets overflow with clothes, blankets, tools, trinkets, toys, and other miscellaneous junk.

items.name: Private Rooms
items.entry: A side entrance leads to a few low rooms where Ruckus lives.

items.name: Storage
items.entry: A storeroom door toward the back of the shop is roped off and bears a hastily scrawled sign that reads, "WARNING! FIRE GHOST. STAY OUT!" Inside the storeroom, jumbled goods cram floor-to-ceiling shelves.

entries.name: Shop Services
entries: The Provisioner Handout lists items available for sale. Give this handout to the players whenever they visit this location. Ruckus might point proudly at some of the illustrations to invite comment about how nice they look.

entries.name: Quest: Fire Ghost
entries: If the characters don't bring up the unusual sign on the storeroom door, Ruckus soon mentions it and asks for their help in resolving the matter. Read the following boxed text aloud:

"I've been smelling smoke in the storeroom for the past few days. Yesterday I peeked inside and saw a cloaked figure smoldering like an ember—surely it was a fire ghost! I threw a flagon of ale at it to put out the fire, but I haven't dared to enter the room since. Someone braver than me should lay the ghost to rest. Maybe you could do it?"

entries.name: The "Ghost"
entries: The only thing haunting the shopkeeper is his own reckless disorganization. Ruckus recently relocated some inventory to a shelf in his storeroom; the merchandise included a hefty magnifying glass. On sunny days, the light through a high window focuses through the lens on a dusty old cloak, causing it to smolder. It's a major fire hazard.
Ruckus's decision to leave the storeroom alone compounds the danger. If the problem isn't dealt with soon, a conflagration is inevitable.

entries.name: Investigating the Scene
entries: Characters can get at the truth by investigating the jumbled storeroom, where they discover a singed cloak stained with dried ale.

entries.name: Gathering Clues
entries: Characters in the storeroom can gather clues by succeeding on one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}).} At noon each day, sunlight from the window shines on the cloak.
{@b {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}).} High on a shelf near the storeroom window, a magnifying glass protrudes from an open box.

entries.name: Solving the Case
entries: After inspecting the storeroom, the characters can draw their conclusions. A character who considers the evidence and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check correctly deduces the source of the smoke and the risk it poses to Ruckus's shop. A character who gathered one or both clues has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on this check.
If the characters explain the situation, Ruckus is relieved to hear his shop isn't haunted and corrects the fire hazard. As thanks, he pays each character 10 GP and encourages them to spend it here.

entries.name: 6: Trader's Shop
entries: Only bold traders bring goods to the Borderlands.
When the characters arrive at the shop, read the following boxed text aloud:
Awnings extend over weapon racks and armor stands at this trader's shop. Inside, a tall human woman polishes a suit of armor with an oily rag.
The woman is Oleira, the shop's owner. The trader's shop is a family business. She runs it with her two teenage sons, Derlo and Ulmar, who dream of being brave knights rather than shopkeepers.

entries.name: Oleira
entries: {@i Human Shopkeeper}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: This merchant and mother of two deals in wares ranging from common trade goods to curious bric-a-brac.

items.name: Fastidious
items.entry: Oleira can't stand dusty wares. Every item must be spotless.

items.name: Parental
items.entry: Oleira sometimes treats her customers like she does her children.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "A hermit, Xanthe, was cast out of the keep for practicing evil magic. I hear she was in a cult. Think of the children!" (False})
{@i "The keep's two outer gate guards, Bartho and Gala, are both so green. I'm not sure which of them I trust less to protect us." (True})

entries.name: Shop Features
entries: The trader's shop has the following features:

items.name: Indoor Display
items.entry: The shop interior contains minor luxuries such as salt, spices, cloth, and furniture, which Oleira sells only to citizens of the keep. The goods are clean and well organized.

items.name: Outdoor Display
items.entry: When the shop is open, Oleira displays armor and weapons under the awning.

items.name: Warehouse
items.entry: Behind the shop is a small warehouse, where Oleira receives, sorts, and stores goods.

entries.title: A suit of armor for sale

entries.name: Shop Services
entries: The Trader Handout lists items available for sale. Give this handout to the players whenever they visit this location.

entries.name: Quest: Dangerous Stowaway
entries: As the characters browse Oleira's wares, she offers them each 1 GP to unload a wagon while her sons are off watching soldiers train elsewhere in the keep. The delivery is late, so Oleira tells the characters to meet the wagon along the trail.

Unknown to Oleira, the shipment contains a dangerous stowaway. During transit, a nasty ooze slithered onto the wagon and gobbled up its driver. Oozes usually lurk in dark places like caves or dungeons, but they go wherever they can sate their voracious appetites.

entries.name: Ooze Surprise
entries: If the characters agree, the guards at the outer gate nod at them as they exit the keep and head down the trail. When the characters come across the wagon, read the following boxed text aloud:
You find the wagon standing in the middle of the trail with no driver in sight. Some of the crates in the wagon glisten wetly.

A {@creature Gray Ooze Glob|HotB} lurks within the abandoned wagon, waiting to ambush the characters. When the characters approach the wagon, the ooze seeps from the supplies with a hideous squelching noise and fights the characters. Roll Initiative!

entries.name: Preparing for Combat
entries: Use the "{@book Combat|XPHB|1|Combat}" section of the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}, along with the Trail Map and the {@creature Gray Ooze Glob|HotB} stat block, to run this encounter.

entries.name: Reward
entries: After defeating the ooze, carting the goods is straightforward work. When the characters return to Oleira, she's shocked to learn of the ooze—she or her sons could've been seriously harmed.
To show her gratitude, Oleira exceeds her original offer, paying each character 5 GP for their heroism.

entries.name: 7: Bank
entries: The keep's residents and visitors store their most valuable belongings and savings in the bank.
When the characters arrive at the bank, read the following boxed text aloud:
This one-story bank sports a teller's window with a drop-down counter. A bespectacled halfling woman in a silk tabard sits behind the glass. Outside, a bored human guard stands watch.
The banker, Quink, relies on the keep's soldiers for protection. Yvette is stationed here most days to discourage anyone from hassling Quink.

entries.name: Quink
entries: {@i Halfling Banker}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: Quink is a miserly moneylender.

items.name: Frugal
items.entry: Quink never budges on matters of money.

items.name: Garrulous
items.entry: Conversations with Quink last twice as long as they should.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Good supplies are a sound investment. Ruckus at the provisioner's shop can outfit you with quality gear." (True})
{@i "I've heard dragons are a bit like bankers—we obsess over every coin. If you ever encounter a dragon, don't touch its hoard unless you want to meet its wrath." (True})

entries.name: Yvette
entries: {@i Human Bank Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard|XMM}

entries: This corrupt guard exploits her station for selfish ends.

items.name: Bitter
items.entry: Yvette thinks the world owes her.

items.name: Grifter
items.entry: Yvette is always hunting for new ways to get rich quick.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "There's an alms box at the temple that usually contains a few gold pieces. I hear Fazzir doesn't even lock it." (True})
{@i "If you find yourself face to face with an owlbear, just play dead. It will quickly get bored and move on." (False})

entries.name: Bank Features
entries: The bank has the following features:

items.name: Service Counter
items.entry: Sturdy hinges connect a wooden drop-down counter to the bank's window. At night, Quink folds up the counter and closes the window, then secures both with an iron grate.

items.name: Vault
items.entry: A locked, reinforced door connects the bank teller's office to Quink's private quarters and a vault. Inside the vault are several strongboxes containing 250 GP worth of deposited wealth.

entries.name: Bank Services
entries: The bank offers the following services:

items.name: Take Out a Loan
items.entry: A character can borrow up to 10 GP from the bank with an interest rate of 1 GP per day. There's no minimum payment due, but if the loan is left unpaid for long, word of the character's financial insolvency spreads throughout the keep.

items.name: Deposit and Withdraw Money
items.entry: A character can deposit gold and other valuables at the bank. They can withdraw some or all the deposited savings during regular business hours at no cost.

entries.name: Quest: Bank Job
entries: At the service counter, Quink asks the characters if they're adventurers looking for work. If they say yes, she leans in close and speaks to them in hushed tones. Read the following boxed text aloud:

"Yvette here is a lousy guard. There was a break-in recently on her watch, and the burglar got away. I fear the culprit might attempt another break-in, and I'd like you to prevent the heist—quietly. I can pay you a lump sum of twenty gold pieces for your services. What do you say?"
If the characters accept, Quink continues:

"I'd like you to stake out the bank tonight. If you see a burglar trying to enter, intervene and convince the criminal to leave at once. Remember, I'm paying for discretion. If you try to give the thief a trouncing, it will no doubt cause a scene. I want this matter resolved without violence."
Quink believes the culprit lives in the keep.

entries.name: Thief in the Night
entries: That night, a masked thief stealthily approaches the bank's door and attempts to pick its lock. The thief is Indifferent toward and wary of the characters if approached but doesn't immediately run away.
As an Influence action, a character can dissuade the thief and make one of these ability checks:
{@b {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character tells the thief a lie, like saying the guards are coming.
{@b {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}).} The character convinces the thief to pursue a different line of work.
{@b {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB}).} The character threatens the thief, who abandons the heist.
On a successful check, the thief lingers long enough for the characters to recognize Yvette, the bank's usual guard! On a failed check, she flees before they can get a good look at her.

entries.name: Reward
entries: Quink pays the characters 20 GP for stopping the heist as promised. If they also reveal the thief's identity, Quink is flabbergasted but adds a 10 GP bonus for the characters' exceptional work. Soon after, two guards arrive and arrest Yvette. After the arrest, Yvette no longer appears at this location.

entries.name: 8: Traveler's Inn
entries: This inn caters to weary travelers, merchants, and adventurers. It offers a range of accommodations depending on a customer's budget.
When the characters arrive at the inn, read the following boxed text aloud:
The smell of soap and lavender fills this warm inn. The front door opens to a lobby staffed by a stout dwarf behind a lacquered wooden counter with a shiny call bell.
"Greetings," the dwarf says in a deep voice. "Are you looking to book a bed for the night?"
The dwarf is Haldryck, the innkeeper.

entries.name: Haldryck
entries: {@i Dwarf Innkeeper}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: Jovial and accommodating, Haldryck is a fast friend to anyone who visits his inn.

items.name: Epicurean
items.entry: Good food and drink are the keys to Haldryck's heart.

items.name: Overseller
items.entry: Haldryck advertises his inn's basic necessities—like clean sheets and doors with locks—as luxury amenities.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The food at the tavern is the best in the Borderlands!" (Doubtful})
{@i "My inn is the only place visitors to the keep can stay overnight." (False})

entries.name: Inn Features
entries: The inn has the following features:

items.name: Common Room
items.entry: The common sleeping area is a large, open room with a handful of stiff cots and a crackling hearth. Patrons can also lay out their own sleeping mats on the floor for a safe—albeit uncomfortable—night's sleep.

items.name: Private Rooms
items.entry: Customers with gold to spare can sleep in one of the inn's six private rooms. Each well-appointed room has four beds. Haldryck boasts that the beds in these rooms are bug free.

items.name: Wares
items.entry: Haldryck rents and sells various bedding items, including wool blankets, woven sleeping mats, and pillows stuffed with goose down.

entries.name: Inn Services
entries: The inn offers the following services:

items.name: Rent a Cot
items.entry: Cots in the common room are available to rent for 1 GP per night. Roll {@dice 1d4} for each character who rents a cot. On a 1, the character finds a dead bug on their pillow.

items.name: Rent a Room
items.entry: A private room costs 5 GP per night. Roll {@dice 1d4} for each character who rents a room. On a 4, the character finds 1 GP under their mattress.

entries.name: Quest: Wake-up Call
entries: After making introductions, Haldryck tells the characters they look light on their feet and in possession of good manners. He could use their help. Read the following boxed text aloud:

"Three guests sleeping in the common room this evening requested to be woken before sunrise, but I have a morning errand to attend to, so I won't be able to fulfill my promise to them. I'd like you to wake the early risers in my stead without stirring any of the other guests.
"In exchange, I can offer you a free night's stay in one of my private rooms. There's even one with a window! How does that sound?"
If the characters agree, Haldryck thanks them and describes the three guests who requested wake-up calls before returning to his duties.

entries.name: Waking the Early Risers
entries: When the characters arrive to wake the early risers, twelve people are asleep in the common room. The early risers are scattered about the room, dozing among other guests who don't wish to be disturbed.

To find and wake an early riser without disturbing the other guests, a character must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check. On a failed check, the character still wakes the early riser but bumps a grumpy sleeper in the process, rousing them from their slumber. The characters must make this check three times, one for each early riser.

entries.name: Checking In with Haldryck
entries: For waking the early risers, Haldryck rewards the party 5 GP, recommending they use it to rent a private room. If the characters completed the task without bothering any other guests, Haldryck gives the characters an additional 10 GP for their good work. Otherwise, he mutters about receiving a noise complaint from an unhappy guest.

entries.name: 9: Tavern
entries: Dubbed the Drunken Dragon, this tavern caters to residents and visitors alike and hosts a nightly drinking game.
When the characters arrive at the tavern, read the following boxed text aloud:

The aroma of cooked mutton, fresh bread, and stiff ale wafts from this bustling tavern's doors. Inside, retired soldiers, chatty merchants, and weary travelers dot the taproom. A raised stage in one corner is empty.
A human man in an apron greets you from behind the bar. "Welcome to the Drunken Dragon. What can I getcha?" he asks in a smooth voice.
The man behind the bar is Umbrusk. After taking the characters' orders, Umbrusk invites them to play chug champion (see this {@area location's quest|178|x}).

entries.name: Umbrusk
entries: {@i Human Barkeep}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: Umbrusk serves up drinks, food, and gossip at the keep's tavern.

items.name: Eavesdropper
items.entry: Umbrusk listens to his patrons' conversations.

items.name: Good Memory
items.entry: Umbrusk never forgets a face or name.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "A traveler named Mallyn walks the trails outside the keep. If you meet her, say hello for me! She's my niece." (True})
{@i "Whenever I order a cake, it gets seized by goblins, roadside bandits—you name it. I guess everybody likes dessert." (True})

entries.name: Tavern Features
entries: The tavern has the following features:

items.name: Taproom
items.entry: The tavern's taproom holds a sticky bar counter, ten round tables, and forty chairs in varying states of disrepair.

items.name: Kitchen
items.entry: In addition to hired cooks, Umbrusk's staff includes patrons who couldn't pay their tabs. They all work in a cramped, greasy kitchen behind a swinging door near the bar.

items.name: Stage
items.entry: There's no formal vetting process for who can use the stage; the taproom's rowdy patrons loudly express their enthusiasm—or disdain—for anyone brave enough to perform.

entries.name: Tavern Services
entries: The tavern offers the following services:

items.name: Food and Drink
items.entry: The tavern sells the items listed on the Drunken Dragon Handout. Give this handout to your players whenever they visit this location.

items.name: Buy the House a Round
items.entry: For 20 GP, a character can buy a drink for everyone in the taproom. For the next 24 hours, that character has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) checks made in the keep.

items.name: Solicit Rumors
items.entry: Once per day, a character in the tavern can make a {@dc 10} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check to glean a rumor from the bartender or a chatty patron. On a successful check, roll on the Tavern Rumors table to determine the rumor they learn. The rumor's veracity is noted in parentheses; don't read that part out loud.

entries.caption: Tavern Rumors
rows: "Bree-yark" is a goblin phrase that means "we surrender!" (False)
The keep's banker, Quink, has been having trouble with break-ins recently. (True)
For the right price, the outer gatehouse guards will let anyone into the keep. (False)
Kalista, the keep's blacksmith, doesn't forge weapons anymore. (Partially true; she makes them only for the keep's militia.)

entries.name: Quest: Chug Champion
entries: The tavern's signature game is a nightly contest called chug champion.

entries.name: Playing the Game
entries: To play chug champion, participants—called "chuggers"—line up at the bar and pay 5 GP each to receive three pints of either heady ale or non-alcoholic cider (their choice). The goal is to drink the pints as quickly as possible over 3 rounds.

Each round, each participating character must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw to quaff the pint in one go. On a failed save, the character drinks too slowly and is eliminated along with a handful of other chuggers. Otherwise, they proceed to the next round. A character who succeeds on all three saves wins the game.

If multiple characters succeed on all three saving throws, compare the results of those chuggers' last saves, rerolling any ties. The character with the highest result places first, the character with the second-highest result places second, and any other characters place third.

entries.name: Winning the Game
entries: The winner receives 25 GP. Second- and third-place chuggers win 15 GP and 10 GP, respectively.

entries.name: 10: Guild House
entries: This guild house offers membership to merchants and artisans, who enjoy benefits such as workshop space, library access, and armed escorts.
When the characters arrive at the guild house, read the following boxed text aloud:
Well-oiled oak beams crisscross the high ceilings of this stately guild house. Quiet murmurs and the sounds of crafting echo among workshops. A staircase ascends to a modest library.
A human woman in a wheelchair emerges from an adjacent office and politely greets you.
The greeter is the guildmaster, Toryn.

entries.name: Toryn
entries: {@i Human Guild Master}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: This guild master helps fellow artisans get a good deal for their wares and services.

items.name: Judgmental
items.entry: Toryn looks down on artisans who refuse to join the guild.

items.name: Witty
items.entry: Toryn says smart things and always has the last word.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Castellan Winvarle is the ultimate authority in the keep." (True})
{@i "The Borderlands are home to all sorts of trades: musicians, mercenaries, treasure-seekers, spies—even monsters can have a profession. My advice? Pay them what they ask." (True})

entries.name: Guild House Features
entries: The guild house has the following features:

items.name: Administration
items.entry: Toryn oversees the guild from a polished but cluttered oak desk in an office with a private elevator.

items.name: Library
items.entry: The guild holds the largest collection of books and scrolls in the keep.

items.name: Workshops
items.entry: Guild members ply their trades in 10-foot-square sections of a spacious room partitioned by hanging curtains.

entries.name: Guild House Services
entries: The guild house offers the following services:

items.name: Customize Equipment
items.entry: A character can hire an artisan to customize their equipment, such as emblazoning a Shield with a symbol of their choice or embellishing the binding of a Spellbook. The standard rate is 5 GP per piece of equipment.

items.name: Research
items.entry: The library contains books on history, magic, and the creatures of the Borderlands. For 1 GP, a character can spend 1 hour researching in the library. The next time that character takes the {@action Study|XPHB} action relating to a subject covered by the library's books, they have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the Intelligence check made as part of that action. A character can benefit from this only once per day.

entries.name: Quest: Chaos Unfurls
entries: Once Toryn learns the characters are adventurers, she tries to hire them. Read the following aloud:

"I recently received a shipment of tempestuous magical scrolls. I need them stored in special scroll cases. If you tackle this chore for me, I'll pay you a total of twenty gold pieces. Be warned: the scrolls have a will of their own."

If the characters agree, Toryn leads them to a storeroom containing a pile of empty scroll cases and a warded chest that holds the scrolls. She instructs the characters to open the chest when they're ready, then wishes them good luck and departs hurriedly.

entries.name: Ensorcelled Scrolls
entries: When the characters open the chest, the scrolls erupt from it in a flurry of whirling parchment and shimmering ink. Roll Initiative.

Each round on Initiative Count 10 (losing Initiative ties), the scrolls fold themselves into weapons and deliver brutal paper cuts. Each character must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d4} Slashing damage. A character reduced to 0 Hit Points by a scroll has the {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} condition but is {@variantrule Stable|XPHB}.
There are two scrolls for every player character in the party. As an action, a character can try to stow a scroll in its case by succeeding on one of the following ability checks:
{@b {@dc 12} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}).} The character deftly plucks a scroll from the air and puts it into a scroll case.
{@b {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}).} The character pacifies a scroll with an arcane gesture, allowing it to be scooped up and peacefully stored.
{@b {@dc 12} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB}).} The character bullies a scroll, causing it to flee into a case.

entries.name: Case Closed
entries: If the characters encase all the scrolls, Toryn pays them 20 GP as promised. If the scrolls knock out all the characters, Toryn finishes the task before tending to the party. The characters wake up in her office with 1 Hit Point each. When the characters come to, Toryn apologizes sheepishly for putting them in so much danger, then awards them 10 GP for their effort.

entries.name: 11: Temple
entries: The temple meets the spiritual needs of the keep. The curate, a human man named Fazzir, guides the temple's daily activities, which include conducting ceremonies, healing injured soldiers, and offering counsel in matters of ethics and morality.
When the characters arrive at the temple, read the following boxed text aloud:
The interior of this tall building has a lofty, majestic air. Rows of benches face an altar at the end of a spacious worship hall. Above the altar is an enormous stained-glass window of a sunrise.
Until recently, the temple's head priest was a human woman named Ivlis, but she recently departed the keep on a long-anticipated pilgrimage.

entries.name: Fazzir
entries: {@i Human Priest}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Curate|HotB}

entries: This spiritual leader offers counsel and healing to all who seek the temple.

items.name: Altruistic
items.entry: Fazzir puts the needs of others before his own.

items.name: Trusting
items.entry: Fazzir always assumes the best of people.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The keep's former priest, Ivlis, left a large collection of books on all matter of subjects—even occult rituals." (True})
{@i "Anyone entering the inner bailey is bound to cross paths with Shannik, sergeant of the guard. I think he's a little too hard on new recruits." (True})

entries.name: DM Secret
entries: {@creature Ivlis|HotB} secretly leads the Cult of Chaos, an evil cult that feeds on destruction and disarray. Her supposed religious journey is a cover for her occult activities, which are detailed in the "{@adventure Caves of Chaos|HotB|1}".

entries.name: Temple Features
entries: The temple has the following features:

items.name: Alms Box
items.entry: A stout pole near the temple's entrance holds a small box for visitors to leave donations. At any given time, the alms box contains {@dice 1d8} GP. The box is unlocked. A character who steals from the alms box must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} for the next 24 hours.

items.name: Sanctuary
items.entry: This spiritual center can accommodate dozens of worshipers. Fazzir delivers sermons from the altar each dawn. His simple lessons appeal to a variety of religious traditions.

items.name: Underground Accommodations
items.entry: Fazzir inhabits modest rooms in the temple's cellar. The cellar also contains two small spare rooms. Fazzir uses these rooms as infirmaries or guest quarters as circumstances demand.

entries.name: Temple Services
entries: The Sacred Services Handout lists available goods and services. Give this handout to the players whenever they visit this location. Fazzir provides the temple's healing and revival services as detailed on the {@creature Curate|HotB} stat block.
May all who act with kindness and virtue Always stand upright.
May neither claw nor steel nor darkness hurt you; Be shielded by the light.

entries.name: Quest: Priestly Duties
entries: In Ivlis's absence, Fazzir is having trouble keeping up with the flood of new responsibilities. He asks the characters to help him with two clerical tasks.

entries.name: Impromptu Blessing
entries: A married couple asked Fazzir to give them a blessing for safe travel for a romantic getaway. Fazzir needs two assistants to perform the ceremony.

To conduct the ceremony properly, two characters must each take the {@action Study|XPHB} action and make a {@dc 10} Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the couple departs the temple with cheer. On a failed check, the couple postpones their trip, uneasy about what their journey might bring.

entries.name: Occult Symbol
entries: Last night, a vandal defaced the temple with a strange symbol. Fazzir doesn't recognize the symbol. He asks the party to scrub away the graffiti.

A blood-red bell is splattered onto the side of the temple in runny paint. A character who inspects the symbol and succeeds on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check recognizes the bell as the mark of the Cult of Chaos and an omen of future turmoil. If informed about the symbol's meaning, Fazzir finds the revelation deeply troubling. The mark washes off easily, but its stain on the priest's mind lingers.

entries.name: Reward
entries: After these tasks, Fazzir gives each character 3 GP regardless of their performance. He is just grateful for their support.

entries.name: Good-Faith Discounts
entries: It's unlikely that the characters will accumulate the gold required to revive a party member. At the DM's discretion, Fazzir might waive any of the fees on the {@adventure Sacred Services Handout|HotB|2|Sacred Services Handout} for those he believes show heroic potential.

entries.name: 12: Inner Gatehouse
entries: This gatehouse houses on-duty soldiers and separates the civilian areas of the keep from the inner bailey ({@area area 13|19a|x}).
When the characters arrive at the inner gatehouse, read the following boxed text aloud:
This gatehouse consists of a broad stone archway framed by a squat building constructed along the keep's inner wall. Battlements line its flat roof, atop which two guards stand watch.
The guards ask the characters about their business, then escort them to Andrella, Captain of the Guard.

entries.name: Andrella
entries: {@i Human Captain of the Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard Captain|XMM}

entries: This captain is strong, stern, and just.

items.name: Perfect Posture
items.entry: Andrella is as strict with her posture as she is with the law.

items.name: Role Model
items.entry: Many of the keep's young people admire Andrella and enjoy her goodhearted mentorship.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "A dastardly bandit, Pral, accosts travelers along the trail. Apparently he's quite handsome; I'm sure he'll look even better behind bars." (True})
{@i "The castellan tells me monsters are drawn to the Caves of Chaos in droves. I wonder why." (True})

entries.name: Gatehouse Features
entries: The gatehouse has the following features:

items.name: Garrison
items.entry: Twenty-four soldiers, including Captain Andrella, are garrisoned in the gatehouse.

items.name: Gate
items.entry: The gate features a massive oak double door. During invasions, soldiers can bar the doors with a heavy timber beam from the other side.

items.name: Murder Holes
items.entry: Guards atop the gatehouse can thrust spears down at invaders through holes in the ceiling of the archway.

entries.name: Gatehouse Services
entries: The gatehouse offers the following service:

items.name: Requisition Uniforms
items.entry: Characters who pledge to defend the keep can requisition uniforms from Andrella free of charge. Give those players one {@item Borderlands Tabard|HotB} each.

entries.name: Quest: Testing the Defenses
entries: Andrella has an unusual request. Once she learns the characters are adventurers, she dismisses the guards and says the following to the party:
"I want to observe how my soldiers would fare in an invasion scenario. As adventurers, you might be able to simulate such a threat.

"I'd like you to sneak past the guards stationed here after sunset and steal a pennant from the other side of the gate. As part of this exercise, you can't harm any on-duty soldiers, but I'll explain the situation if any of you are detained. "Are you up for the challenge?"
In exchange for their work, Andrella offers the characters a total of 25 GP.

entries.name: Infiltrating the Guardhouse
entries: During the night, eight soldiers stand watch outside the gatehouse: six on the roof and another two on the ground before the open gate. If necessary, use the {@creature Guard|XMM} stat block to represent each soldier.
As an action, a character can try to bypass the soldiers and make one of these ability checks:
{@b {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}).} The character slips past the soldiers undetected.
{@b {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}).} The character scales the keep's sheer wall between regular patrols.
{@b {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character fools the soldiers with a disguise or convincing lie.
On a successful check, the character bypasses the soldiers undetected. On a failed check, two soldiers spot the character and take them into custody, but other characters can continue the mission.

entries.name: Debrief with Andrella
entries: If at least one character reaches the pennant without getting caught, Andrella meets them afterward. She pays the party 25 GP as promised. If no characters were spotted, Andrella throws in an extra 15 GP and chastises the soldiers they evaded.

If all the characters are detained before anyone in the party can grab the pennant, Andrella visits the characters in a sparsely furnished detention cell and thanks them for testing her soldiers. She informs the soldiers about the training exercise and smugly pays the characters 25 GP on their release.

entries.name: 13: Inner Bailey
entries: The sheltered inner bailey is where the keep's defenders live and practice combat drills.
When the characters arrive at the inner bailey, read the following boxed text aloud:

Targets and practice dummies dot this courtyard, which contains a large stable and poles with hanging rings. Cavalry soldiers train atop horseback while guards watch the area from the walls and towers that rise around it.
A mountain of a man in heavy armor tromps up to you. "No lollygagging!" he grouses.
The man is the keep's demanding and curmudgeonly sergeant of the guard, Shannik.

entries.name: Shannik
entries: {@i Human Sergeant of the Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard Captain|XMM}

entries: Captain Andrella's second in command brooks no evildoers.

items.name: Brusque
items.entry: When Shannik can substitute a reply with a grunt, he does so.

items.name: Shortsighted
items.entry: Shannik's plans and actions fail to account for long-term repercussions.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "An adventurer is only as good as their gear. Oleira at the trader's shop is a friend of mine. She can sell you armor and weapons." (True})
{@i "A real soldier can sleep off any injury. After a battle, I usually rent a bed at the inn. I always sleep better there." (True})

entries.name: Inner Bailey Features
entries: The inner bailey has the following features:

items.name: Cavalry Stable
items.entry: The bailey contains a stable with thirty horses. These war-trained horses serve as mounts for the keep's cavalry.

items.name: Guard Towers
items.entry: Four towers rise above the bailey, one in each corner. The smallest, to the southeast, holds up to eight guards. The southwest and northeast towers each hold one dozen guards, as well as food stores and other supplies. The Great Tower to the northwest is 60 feet tall.

items.name: Watches
items.entry: Eight soldiers, two atop each tower, watch over the inner bailey at all hours. Use the {@creature Guard|XMM} stat block for these soldiers if necessary.

entries.name: Inner Bailey Services
entries: The inner bailey offers the following service:

items.name: Weapon Upgrade
items.entry: The keep ordered too many crossbows, which untrained recruits can't wield effectively. Shannik wants to trade the weapons for simpler ones. In exchange for 25 GP and a Shortbow, he can provide a character with a {@item Hand Crossbow|XPHB}.

entries.name: Quest: Shannik's Chores
entries: Shannik hires the characters to complete a couple chores around the inner bailey. The characters can refuse his request, but Shannik asks with increasing insistence each time they visit the inner bailey.

entries.name: Disrupting the Charge
entries: Shannik wants to train two green recruits for the cavalry. He has them ride around the bailey for 10 minutes, spearing the hanging rings with lances.

During the exercise, Shannik asks the characters to disrupt the training by distracting the horses or their riders without causing injury to either. A character can do so by succeeding on one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}).} The character guides a horse off course.
{@b {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB}).} The character tries to startle a horse or its rider.

entries.title: A Cavalry Lance Laden with Training Rings

entries.name: Catapult Installation
