entries: Shannik wants to install a catapult atop the Great Tower to defend against invaders. To do so, the characters must succeed on the following ability checks in this order:
{@b {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}).} The character hauls supplies out of the stores in the southwest tower, across the bailey, and up the Great Tower.
{@b {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}).} The character correctly assembles the catapult according to its blueprints.
{@b {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}).} The character calibrates the catapult by test-firing it at a target outside the keep's walls.

This task takes 1 hour. If at least one character succeeds on each check, the party completes the task. The characters can retry failed checks, but if they accumulate three failures, Shannik dismisses them, grumbling about their incompetence.

entries.name: Reward
entries: In exchange for completing a chore, Shannik pays a character 5 GP. A character can complete each of Shannik's chores only once. Thereafter, the sergeant greets the characters with a respectful nod whenever they visit this area.

entries.name: 14: Fortress
entries: The castellan governs the keep from its fortress, a stone stronghold solidly built to withstand assault. Multiple towers rise above the main building, which is 30 feet tall. The fortress shelters emergency resources, municipal chambers, and the keep's armed forces. Militaristic banners and upholstered furniture decorate its dignified interior.
When the characters arrive at the keep fortress, read the following boxed text aloud:

Two round towers with pointed roofs flank this tiered stronghold. Archers march along its stone parapets, watching for signs of trouble. Two guards stand outside the fortress's iron doors; they acknowledge passersby with stern nods.

entries.name: Fortress Features
entries: The fortress has the following features:

items.name: Armory
items.entry: Barding and lances for the keep's cavalry—thirty troops strong—are stored here, though the equipment is off-limits to the characters.

items.name: Barracks
items.entry: Sparsely furnished quarters throughout the fortress can collectively accommodate up to thirty-six soldiers at once.

items.name: Great Hall
items.entry: A spacious hall in the fortress hosts ceremonies, proclamations, and other receptions.

items.name: Private Chambers
items.entry: Two lavishly decorated rooms are reserved for guests of the keep, while another belongs to the castellan.

items.name: Towers
items.entry: Two peaked towers rise from the fortress.

items.name: Undercroft
items.entry: Beneath the fortress are cellars containing vast provision stores, a cistern, and a dungeon with four stout cells for detainees and prisoners. If Yvette was arrested at the bank (see {@area area 7|168|x}), she is detained in one of the cells.

entries.name: Fortress Services
entries: The fortress offers the following services:

items.name: Defense
items.entry: In times of crisis, the castellan can muster up to thirty-six trained soldiers from the fortress to defend the keep. The fortress also provides refuge during incursions.

items.name: Seat of Government
items.entry: During the day, the castellan and his two assistants conduct business in the main building, where they hold audience with citizens and visitors of the keep.

entries.name: Quest: Official Errands
entries: Each official in the fortress spurs the characters to explore a different adventure setting.

entries.name: Dwern the Scribe
entries: The castellan's scribe, a dwarf man named Dwern, sits at a tidy desk in an austere office, documenting changes to the keep's inventory in a heavy ledger.
When the characters visit Dwern, he issues the following quest:

"I've commissioned a map of the wilderness beyond the keep. However, the map is sorely lacking in detail, and few are willing to brave the wilds to properly survey them—but you look like you're made of sterner stuff.
"If you help me finish my map by exploring the surrounding lands, I'll compensate you fairly."

If the characters explore three or more wilderness regions (see the "{@adventure Wilderness|HotB|3}" section) and report their findings to Dwern, the scribe pays them a handsome reward: a large, glittering gemstone (worth 100 GP), which they can sell to the jeweler for gold (see {@area area 3|13d|x}).

entries.name: Dwern
entries: {@i Dwarf Scribe}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: This gruff scribe prefers the company of books over people.

items.name: Bookworm
items.entry: Dwern has read more books than anyone else in the keep.

items.name: Curmudgeonly
items.entry: Dwern is ill-tempered toward younger people—which, to him, are most people.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The guild house's library boasts a modest but impressive collection of books on history and magic." (True})
{@i "There's an ancient statue somewhere in the forests north of the keep. It was once the site of strange rituals. Some say it still is." (True})

entries.name: Elandra the Adviser
entries: The castellan's trusted adviser, an elf woman named Elandra, operates in one of the towers. Carpets and tapestries decorate her chamber.
When the characters visit Elandra, she issues the following quest:
"While Castellan Winvarle protects the keep from outside threats, it's my duty to preserve the peace within its walls and ensure its citizens are content.

"I'd like you to visit a few businesses within the keep and help their owners with any odd jobs they might have. I recently acquired an item of arcane significance. Assist me in this effort, and the item is yours."

If the characters complete three quests within the keep and report back to Elandra, she rewards them with one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: Elandra
entries: {@i Elf Adviser}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: Elandra provides guidance to the castellan and citizens of the keep.

items.name: Cautious
items.entry: When presented with a choice, Elandra typically prefers the option with the least amount of risk.

items.name: Complainer
items.entry: Nothing is ever good enough for Elandra.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Every night, the tavern hosts a rowdy little drinking game with prizes. It's not for me." (True})
{@i "Kalista, the keep's blacksmith, doesn't sell weapons to adventurers. If you want to know why, ask her." (True})

entries.name: Winvarle
entries: {@i Human Castellan}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Knight|XMM}

entries: The keep's noble commander leads his soldiers whenever the keep comes under attack.

items.name: Idealistic
items.entry: Winvarle's ideals are rooted in lofty notions of righteousness.

items.name: Oblivious
items.entry: While he excels at battle strategy, Winvarle scarcely knows the inner workings of his own keep.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The Cult of Chaos is an affront to all that is good." (True})
{@i "Anyone can pledge to defend the keep. Talk to Andrella in the inner gatehouse if you'd like to join the keep's defenders." (True})

entries.name: Winvarle the Castellan
entries: The keep's noble castellan, an human man named Winvarle, holds court daily in the great hall. A keen strategist, Winvarle casts his vigilant gaze toward the Caves of Chaos, where rumors of a sinister cult have surfaced (see the "{@adventure Caves of Chaos|HotB|1}").
When the characters visit Winvarle, he issues the following quest:

"Your arrival is fortuitous. I've heard whispers of a nefarious cult—the self-proclaimed Cult of Chaos—that reportedly operates in a cave network to the northeast. I believe the source of the cult's power resides in one of those caves.

"These lands yearn for heroes. For the good of the Borderlands and the people under my charge, I humbly ask you to investigate these rumors and, if need be, quash this evil before it reaches the keep."
Winvarle claims this quest is its own reward, but he adds that the Caves of Chaos abound with treasure, hoping to entice any characters who seek only to fill their coffers.
Castellan Winvarle also encourages the characters to meet with his adviser and scribe, who might have other tasks for them to complete.

entries.name: Heroes' Return

entries.title: Castellan Winvarle and the citizens of the keep celebrate the characters' heroic deeds

entries: If the characters return to this location at level 3, having fulfilled all three keep officials' quests (detailed in the previous sections), they receive a heroes' welcome. That evening, Castellan Winvarle throws a celebration in the characters' honor and invites the citizens of the keep to participate in the festivities. At your discretion, any of the NPCs within the keep might be present at the celebration to mingle with the characters and show their appreciation.

At the height of the revelry, the castellan publicly thanks the characters and presents them a writ of congratulations. Give the players the Castellan's Letter Handout, which might inspire future adventures involving the Keep on the Borderlands.
Noble Adventurers,
I extend to you my deepest thanks. Your gallant efforts have forestalled the forces of chaos and made the Borderlands a safer place. Where there was once uncertainty, there is now hope.

Through your valiant deeds, you have proven yourselves to be more than mere mercenaries or vagabond explorers—you are heroes of the highest caliber. You have done an incredible service to the citizens of this keep, ensuring they can prosper in peace.

As a token of my appreciation, I have reserved a chamber in the fortress for you. You and your companions may come and go in the keep as you please. Henceforth, consider it a base from which you can embark on future adventures, no doubt for the betterment of these lands and the people who call them home.
Gratefully,
{@b Winvarle}
Castellan of the Keep

entries.name: Ending the Adventure
entries: Castellan Winvarle's celebration marks the end of this adventure, but there's still plenty to explore after that. The characters can continue to adventure in the Keep on the Borderlands, the {@adventure Caves of Chaos|HotB|1}, and the {@adventure Wilderness|HotB|3} (detailed in each respective section) until they've experienced all the Borderlands has to offer. You can also use them to tell stories of your own.

If you wish to advance these characters beyond level 3 and create new adventures for them, you need the core rules: the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB}, the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|XDMG}, and the {@book Monster Manual|XMM}.

data.name: Wilderness
entries: The wilds of the Borderlands teem with dangerous animals and ravenous monsters.

entries.name: DM Secret
entries: This is for the Dungeon Master's eyes only. Unless text appears in a read-aloud box (like the one below), don't read it to the players.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: The {@adventure Wilderness Map|HotB|3|Map: Wilderness (DM Version) View Unlabeled Version} displays all the regions characters can visit in this section of the adventure. The player version of this map doesn't reveal the contents of each wilderness region, only the general geographic features. Share that map with your players. The Caves of Chaos and the Keep on the Borderlands aren't labeled on this version of the map so the players don't confuse them with wilderness regions.
To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
Your adventuring party enters the wilderness. Mysteries await you in this untamed land. Where do you want to go?
The Wilderness Regions table summarizes the regions in the order they appear within this section. If fully explored, each region provides about 60–90 minutes of gameplay.

Each region is roughly the same difficulty, but the Trail region functions as a tutorial with helpful sidebars. If this is your first time as the DM, encourage the players to start there. Otherwise, have them choose a region shown on the map.
Once the player characters choose a region, go to that region and review its "What You Need to Play" section.

entries.caption: Wilderness Regions
rows: Friendly travelers and no-good bandits alike use this dirt road.
These majestic forests shelter wily fey and occult secrets.
Territorial lizardfolk and a spy for hire lurk in this wetland.
Giant spiders plague this vast stand of conifers.

entries.name: Exploring the Wilderness
entries: Wilderness encounters occur across large tracts of unmapped backcountry. The text tells you when to use a map and monsters; otherwise, you can resolve encounters using words and imagination.

entries.name: Region Descriptions
entries: Each description of a wilderness region has the following sections:

items.name: Features
items.entry: Important features about the region, such as its lighting, appear here. The text assumes the characters explore the wilderness during the day and camp or return to the keep at night.

items.name: Getting Started
items.entry: This section provides setup instructions for the DM and introduces the region to the characters with thematic read-aloud text.

items.name: Encounters
items.entry: This section presents encounters that might occur in the region. Each encounter's text details what challenge the characters must overcome.

entries.name: Combat
entries: Some encounters pit the characters against foes that mean them harm, such as wild animals or greedy bandits. See the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} for how to run a combat encounter.
The following stat blocks are used in this section:

entries.name: Resting
entries: The dangers of the wilds keep travelers on their toes. The characters can take only {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short Rests} while exploring a wilderness region. To take a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, characters must visit the keep (see "{@adventure Keep on the Borderlands|HotB|2}"). For more on {@book resting|XPHB|1|Resting}, see the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}.

entries.name: Leaving the Wilderness
entries: The characters can leave the wilderness any time they choose, provided they aren't in combat. If they return to a region later, it's as they left it.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: In this adventure, the characters can gain a level by exploring different regions. After the characters complete at least one encounter in all four regions, everyone in the party gains 1 level. This advancement occurs only once. If the characters are already level 3, they don't gain a level for achieving this milestone.

entries.name: Region 1: Trail
entries: This dirt trail connects the Keep on the Borderlands to the Caves of Chaos and the lands beyond.

entries.name: Trail Features
entries: The trail has the following features:

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The trail is illuminated with {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

items.name: Terrain
items.entry: The 10-foot-wide trail is well kept and mostly flat. Spaces off the trail, however, are {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Features
entries: This section presents special features about the region. Use these to enhance your descriptions or handle situations where rules like lighting or terrain are relevant.
The {@book rules glossary|XPHB|10} in the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} defines any capitalized rules such as {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
You travel along a well-kept trail east of the Keep on the Borderlands. Gnarled tree roots and big rocks mark the edges of the ten-foot-wide path.

entries.name: Boxed Text
entries: Text that appears in a box like the one in this section is meant to be read aloud or paraphrased when the characters first arrive at a location or under a specific circumstance, as described in the text.

Boxed text is included for the region in general and for each encounter in it. Read the region's boxed text aloud before choosing the encounter, then read the boxed text aloud for that encounter to begin it.
The characters continue down the trail. Along the way, they face one or more encounters (detailed in the following section). The length of the characters' journey is up to you.

entries.name: Trail Encounters
entries: Each time the characters use the trail, roll once on the Trail Encounters table to determine what the characters encounter. If this is your first time being the DM, run the encounters in the order presented.

entries.name: Random Tables
entries: You can use tables like this one to randomly determine parts of the adventure. In this case, roll {@dice 1d4} to randomly determine what the characters encounter on the trail. Alternatively, you can forgo rolling and simply choose an encounter from the table.

entries.name: Theater of the Mind
entries: While the "{@area Bandit Ambush|1e0|x}" encounter later in this region uses a map, the "Looted Wagon" encounter happens in your collective imaginations!

entries.name: Looted Wagon

entries: A wagon stands on the trail ahead. The driver and horses are nowhere to be seen.

The wagon was looted by bandits, who stole the horses and scared away the driver. Led by a local menace named Pral, these bandits frequently accost travelers along the trail (as happens in the "{@area Bandit Ambush|1e0|x}" encounter described later in this adventure).
A character who inspects the wagon can make one of the following ability checks to learn more about it. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}).} The character deduces the wagon was ambushed by bandits.
{@b {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}).} The character discovers a striking bootprint left by Pral. The heel is monogrammed with the letter {@i P}.
{@b {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}).} The character finds treasure the bandits missed (see below).

entries.name: Ability Checks
entries: When the outcome of an action is uncertain, the game uses a {@dice d20} roll to determine success or failure. This is called a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}. An ability check is one type of D20 Test. Here's how to run the ability check in the "Looted Wagon" encounter:

items: {@b Describe the Scene}. Read the boxed text to paint a mental picture of the scene.
{@b Ask the Players, "What Do You Do?"} If the players aren't sure how to respond, suggest ways they could glean more information, like looking for tracks.

{@b Narrate the Results}. The Difficulty Class (DC) for each listed ability check is 13. This number represents the difficulty of the task. If the total of the {@dice d20} and its modifiers equals or exceeds 13, the check succeeds. On a 12 or lower, it fails. The encounter's description tells you what happens on a successful check. In this encounter, nothing happens on a failed check, but the character can try again.

items.name: Example
items.entry: The Cleric searches the wagon and makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check. The player rolls a {@dice d20} and adds their character's {@skill Perception|XPHB} modifier (+5) for a total of 17. The check succeeds, and the Cleric finds the treasure.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The wagon holds supplies intended for the keep: animal feed, bales of hay, and sacks of freshly milled flour. Stashed in one of the sacks is a purse that contains 12 GP.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Treasure entries detail loot in an area, such as Gold Pieces (GP). Whenever a player character finds gold, give that player Gold Pieces equal to the listed value, which is tracked on their character sheet. Encourage players to split their treasure as evenly as possible.

entries.name: Talkative Traveler

entries: A young woman with a massive backpack and an eager smile hikes toward you along the trail. The traveler waves at you excitedly.

"Good day!" she says. "I'm Mallyn. Might you be adventurers? I ask because I've been out here looking for adventures of my own—to no avail. After camping out here for days, I still don't have any tales worth telling. Do you?"

entries.name: Mallyn
entries: {@i Human Traveler}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: This young wayfarer's heart is filled with wanderlust.

items.name: Easy Come, Easy Go
items.entry: Mallyn doesn't get attached to possessions or acquaintances.

items.name: Inquisitive
items.entry: Mallyn eagerly asks strangers lots of questions.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Don't wander into the fens unless you're looking for trouble. The lizardfolk there don't like visitors." (True})
{@i "My uncle Umbrusk runs the tavern in the keep. He hears all kinds of gossip in the taproom." (True})

entries: Mallyn, a {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} wanderer, is looking for tales of derring-do from brave adventurers. She stops to ask the characters to tell stories of their exploits.
A character can take a minute to tell Mallyn a story and make one of the following ability checks to impress her. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character spins a grand yarn about a harrowing experience that never happened.
{@b {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}).} The character vividly recounts a legendary story through song, dramatic reenactment, or interpretive dance.

If at least one character succeeds on the check, Mallyn thanks the party and gives them a pouch she found on the trail. Otherwise, she encourages them to keep adventuring until they have something more interesting to share. Regardless, Mallyn prefers to travel alone and doesn't accompany the characters on their journey if invited.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The pouch Mallyn found contains 10 GP.

entries.name: Attitudes
entries: Every creature has a starting attitude toward the characters: {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly}, {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}, or {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} (see the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}). Regardless, creatures defend themselves in combat.

entries.name: Game Trail

entries: You spot a regal elk on the trail beside a dense thicket. Startled by your approach, the elk lopes into the thorny thicket. "Blast!" cries a husky voice from somewhere in the brambles.
A character can safely navigate the thicket to the source of the noise by succeeding on one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}).} The character follows the narrow game trail used by the elk.
{@b {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}).} The character knows how to avoid the brambles' thorns.
On a failed check, a character scrambles through but takes {@damage 1d4} Piercing damage from the thorns.

entries.name: Hidden Glen
entries: A hidden glen lies on the other side of the game trail. Dozens of elk graze here in peace. Hiding in the bushes is Haldryck, a {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} innkeeper who likes to hunt. (Haldryck also appears in "{@area Keep on the Borderlands|16a|x}".)
Haldryck asks the characters to keep his hunting spot a secret. If they agree, he gives the characters 5 GP and encourages them to spend it at his inn when next they visit the keep.

entries.name: Social Interaction
entries: Player characters meet many different people while adventuring. As DM, you assume the roles of these nonplayer characters, whom you can embody through either active or descriptive roleplaying (detailed below). Players also use one or both of these approaches to roleplay their characters.

items.name: Active Roleplaying
items.entry: In active roleplaying, you speak with a character's voice and might echo their body language, like an actor taking on a role. You still need to describe things that can't reasonably be acted out.

entries: An active approach to roleplaying Haldryck in the "Game Trail" encounter might involve you pretending to hide behind imaginary foliage and speaking in hushed tones.

items.name: Descriptive Roleplaying
items.entry: In descriptive roleplaying, you draw on your mental image of the character, saying what the character does and how they do it.

entries: In the "{@area Bandit Ambush|1e0|x}" encounter, a descriptive approach to roleplaying Pral, a smarmy bandit captain, might involve you describing his flashy smile or confident swagger. You might tell the players that he holds out his hand expectantly for the characters' gold.

entries.name: Haldryck
entries: {@i Dwarf Innkeeper}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: Jovial and accommodating, Haldryck is a fast friend to anyone who visits his inn.

items.name: Epicurean
items.entry: Good food and drink are the keys to Haldryck's heart.

items.name: Overseller
items.entry: Haldryck advertises his inn's basic necessities—like clean sheets and doors with locks—as luxury amenities.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The food at the tavern is the best in the Borderlands!" (Doubtful})
{@i "My inn is the only place visitors to the keep can stay overnight." (False})

entries.name: Bandit Ambush

entries: A handsome man in a green-and-gold tunic and fancy boots saunters out of the bushes. "Hello," he says casually as he blocks your path. "I'm Pral. Perhaps you've heard of me. Who am I kidding? Of course you have!"
Pral draws a sword. "Your money and your equipment, please. This is a robbery."

{@creature Pral|HotB} leads a local gang of bandits. Three {@creature Bandit|XMM|Bandits} hide in the nearby bushes. Pral and the bandits are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} to the characters.
If the characters don't relinquish their gold or talk their way out of the situation, Pral gives the signal for the bandits to spring out (see the "Fighting the Bandits" section).

entries.name: Adjusting the Difficulty
entries: To make the encounter easier, you can reduce the number of {@creature Bandit|XMM|Bandits}, or you can add another bandit to increase the difficulty.

entries.name: Avoiding a Fight
entries: As an {@action Influence|XPHB} action, a character can try to defuse the situation and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}).} The character lies to Pral to gain safe passage, perhaps by pretending to be a fellow bandit.
{@b {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}).} The character convinces Pral that violence isn't necessary.
{@b {@dc 13} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation|XPHB}).} The character pressures Pral into reconsidering the ambush.

entries.name: Advantage/Disadvantage
entries: Sometimes a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB} is modified by special situations called {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} and {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}, which reflect positive and negative circumstances, respectively. See the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} for more on Advantage and Disadvantage.
In the "Bandit Ambush" encounter, Pral is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile}, so characters have Disadvantage on checks to influence him and thus avoid a fight.

items.name: Roll Two D20s
items.entry: When a roll has either Advantage or Disadvantage, roll a second {@dice d20} when you make the roll. Use the higher of the two rolls if you have Advantage, and use the lower roll if you have Disadvantage.

items.name: Example
items.entry: A Rogue tries to smooth things over with Pral by pretending to be a bandit. The Rogue makes a Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check with Disadvantage.

entries: The player rolls two d20s and adds their character's {@skill Deception|XPHB} modifier (+4) to both results to get two totals: 16 and 9. They use the lower roll, which falls short of the DC of 13, so the check fails—Pral and his bandits start combat! If this check had instead been made with Advantage, it would have succeeded.
On a successful check, Pral lets the characters pass unharmed. On a failed check, Pral signals the bandits to emerge (see the following section).

entries.name: Fighting the Bandits
entries: In the case of combat, read the following to begin:
Pral {@i tsks} in disapproval. He snaps his fingers, prompting more bandits to spring from the bushes with weapons drawn. In an instant, you're surrounded—roll Initiative!

Pral and his bandits are brigands, not murderers. A character reduced to 0 Hit Points by Pral or his cohorts has the {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} condition but is {@variantrule Stable|XPHB}. If all the characters are defeated by Pral's band, they wake up 1 hour later on the trail with 1 Hit Point—and 10 fewer Gold Pieces or no Gold Pieces if they have fewer than 10 GP—each, along with a mocking note penned by Pral. At your discretion, Pral might reappear to the characters the next time they explore this region to rob them again.

entries.name: Combat
entries: Here's how a combat encounter with Pral and his bandits ought to play out:

items: {@b Describe the Scene}. Read the boxed text aloud. Then say, "Roll Initiative!" to signal the start of combat. Pral gets his own Initiative roll. Roll once separately for the bandits, who all act on the same turn.
{@b Players React}. In combat, the characters and the bandits act on their turns.

entries: Use the {@link D&D Beyond Basic Rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024} to run this encounter.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Stashed in the bushes are the recent ill-gotten gains stolen by Pral's band. If the characters defeat Pral and his band, they find a sack that contains 20 GP and one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: Magic Items
entries: Some treasure entries contain magic items, objects imbued with arcane might. Whenever a player character finds a magic item, roll on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: Region 2: Woods
entries: North of the keep sprawls a vast forest, home to hardy oaks, meaty mushrooms, and stores of primal magic. Wherever one goes in the woods, mystery and adventure abound.

entries.name: Woods Features
entries: The woods have the following feature:

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The thick forest canopy filters sunlight from above, resulting in only {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB}.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
Dappled sunlight trickles through the canopy of this old-growth forest. Felled trees, shrubs, and mushrooms dot the forest floor.

entries.name: Woods Encounters
entries: Each time the characters explore this region, roll once on the Woods Encounters table to determine what the characters encounter.

entries.name: Hermit's Hut

entries: After a couple hours of hiking, you happen on a humble hut made from sheets of sturdy bark and blankets of moss. Sweet-smelling smoke wafts from its chimney. The hut's wooden door is shut.

A hermit named Xanthe lives here. Banished months ago from the keep, Xanthe is initially {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters, who she believes have come to harass her.

A character who tries to convince Xanthe that they bear no ill will can make a {@dc 12} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) check. A successful check improves Xanthe's attitude to {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent}, and the hermit invites the party into her hut, where she shares her story and the rumors on her NPC Card. On a failed check, Xanthe slams the door in their faces.

entries.name: Xanthe
entries: {@i Elf Hermit}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: One of the Borderlands' oldest and wisest residents was banished from the keep for crimes she didn't commit.

items.name: Bad Reputation
items.entry: Xanthe was wrongfully exiled for using occult magic.

items.name: Distrustful
items.entry: Xanthe doesn't trust strangers.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "A spy named Jacko prowls the fens. Be wary if you meet him. He'll do anything for coin—even kill." (True})
{@i "The temple's head priest is a demon worshiper." (Partially true; Xanthe is referring to Ivlis, the former priest})

entries.name: Occult Ritual

entries: Eventually, you come across an eerie statue in a forest clearing. Strange runes are etched into the stone idol. Four human figures in occult robes gather around the statue, chanting ominously.

Four {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists} conduct a ritual around this ancient statue. They belong to the Cult of Chaos, a faction that delights in death and disarray. They are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward those not garbed in their cult's attire but don't immediately notice the characters.
The cultists continue intoning until their ritual is complete or interrupted. If disturbed, they fight.

entries.name: Adjusting the Difficulty
entries: To make this encounter easier, reduce the number of {@creature Cultist|XMM|Cultists}. Conversely, you can make this encounter more challenging by adding one or more {@creature Zombie|XMM|Zombies}, which aid the cultists as undead thralls.

entries.name: Fooling the Cultists
entries: The cultists are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward any character wearing a Cultist's Robe, which they might have obtained in the Caves of Chaos (see "{@adventure Caves of Chaos|HotB|1}"). If a character approaches in this disguise, the cultists solemnly motion for the character to join the ritual, but they begin combat if the character refuses.

entries.name: Completing the Ritual
entries: If the characters join the ritual—or observe it without drawing attention—the statue's runes begin to glow with an eerie red light. After 10 minutes, the sky darkens, and the statue suddenly splits in two with a loud crack. Moments later, a wicked, disembodied laugh echoes throughout the forest. The cultists then disband.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The characters can take robes from the defeated cultists. For each robe they take, give the players a {@item Cultist's Robe|HotB}.

entries.name: Sacred Spring

entries: Deep in the heart of the forest, the foliage parts to reveal a tranquil grove where a natural spring burbles. Rays of sunlight create a silvery glow about the crystal-clear pool.
This sacred spring is infused with primal magic.

entries.name: Healing Water
entries: A character who takes an action to drink from the spring regains 5 Hit Points. Once a character regains Hit Points from the spring, they can't do so again until they finish a Long Rest.

entries.name: Destroying the Chaos Bell
entries: If the party has the Chaos Bell from the {@area Shrine of Evil Chaos|0f6|x} (see "{@adventure Caves of Chaos|HotB|1}"), a character can submerge the evil artifact in this sacred spring. If this is done at night while the spring is bathed in moonlight, the bell turns to glittering ash.

entries.name: Sparring Sprites

entries: Farther into the woods, four diminutive, winged warriors flit between oversized toadstools and mossy logs, firing needlelike arrows from tiny bows. One of them calls out to you.
"Well met, giant travelers! We are training for battle," he reports. "Care to spar with us?"

Four {@creature Sprite Skirmisher|HotB|Sprite Skirmishers} spar vigorously in this clearing. The sprites are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters but interested in testing their mettle against the party.

entries.name: Sparring with the Sprites
entries: If the characters agree to spar with the pugnacious fey, the bout proceeds as a nonlethal combat encounter. The sprites bow gracefully, then ready their weapons. Roll Initiative.

The sprites fight valiantly but with restraint. A player character reduced to 0 Hit Points by a sprite has the {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} condition and is {@variantrule Stable|XPHB}. The sprites expect similar treatment by the characters.

If all the sprites are defeated, they quickly rouse themselves and commend the characters on their tactical prowess. If all the characters are defeated instead, the sprites wait for the characters to wake up—1 hour later and with 1 Hit Point each—to thank them for helping the sprites train.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In exchange for the characters' spirited participation, the sprites reward the party with one magic item; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: Region 3: Fens
entries: This sodden wetland is home to dangerous wildlife, canny foes, and squelching mud.

entries.name: Fens Features
entries: The fens have the following features:

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: The fens are in {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}.

items.name: Reeds
items.entry: Tall, slender reeds grow throughout the soggy wetland. Areas with reeds are {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB} and {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

items.name: Standing Water
items.entry: Shallow, soupy pools of murk pervade the fens. The water is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
Mosquitoes buzz about the stands of cattails and gnarled trees in these squashy, stagnant fens. Croaking frogs, chirping cicadas, and squawking birds create an incessant din.

entries.name: Fens Encounters
entries: Each time the characters explore this region, roll once on the Fens Encounters table to determine what the characters encounter.

entries.name: Flock of Stirges

entries: Your journey halts at a narrow creek bed stained with blood. Near the shore, a giant river rat lies dead in the mud. The carcass is shriveled as if drained of its bodily fluids.
Suddenly, a flock of horrid creatures erupts from the reeds. Each has barbed, leathery wings and a long, sharp proboscis. Roll initiative!
Three {@creature Stirge|XMM|Stirges} descend on the characters. These bloodthirsty creatures can't be reasoned with; the {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} stirges fight to the death.

entries.name: Adjusting the Difficulty
entries: To make this encounter easier, you can reduce the number of {@creature Stirge|XMM|Stirges}, or you can increase the difficulty by adding one or more {@creature Gnoll Warrior|XMM|Gnoll Warriors} drawn here by the scent of blood.

entries.name: Lizardfolk Swamp

entries: Deeper into the fens, mounds of mud rise above the fetid water and reeds. You spot a glint of gold amid the mud.

The fen's territorial lizardfolk denizens use these mounds to conceal their treasure. Two {@creature Lizardfolk Warden|HotB|Lizardfolk Wardens} hide among the reeds, watching over the mounds. The lizardfolk have the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition and are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters.
After 1 minute, the lizardfolk appear and tersely command the characters to leave at once. If the characters refuse, the lizardfolk fight.

entries.name: Detecting the Lizardfolk
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can scan the mud mounds for signs of danger, detecting the lizardfolk with a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Fighting the Lizardfolk
entries: If a character approaches the mound or disturbs the treasure (see below), the lizardfolk leap out and start combat. Characters who failed to detect the lizardfolk before the ambush have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on their Initiative rolls. The lizardfolk fight fiercely in defense of their possessions.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Hidden in the mounds are 20 GP and one gemstone (worth 100 GP).

entries.name: Spy's Campsite

entries: The air is still in this corner of the fens. Just ahead, a curved stand of reeds conceals a secluded campsite with a still-smoldering firepit. The reeds sway and rustle in the muggy breeze.
This campsite belongs to {@creature Jacko|HotB}, a notorious spy for hire. Jacko hides in the surrounding foliage. He is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters.

entries.name: Detecting Jacko
entries: As a {@action Search|XPHB} action, a character can survey the campsite for clues to its inhabitant's whereabouts and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}).} The character spots the glint of Jacko's blade in the reeds.
{@b {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}).} The character spots faint tracks that lead to the spy.
On a successful check, Jacko emerges from the tall reeds and commends the party on finding his hideout. He then offers his services to the party.

entries.name: Hiring Jacko
entries: Plucky do-gooders aren't Jacko's usual clientele, but for 25 GP, he offers to join the characters in a single fight anywhere in the wilderness. If the party contains a Rogue or a character with the Criminal background, Jacko offers a 5 GP discount. The shady halfling advertises his services as "all inclusive" and "no questions asked" while performing a cutthroat gesture.

If a player character hires Jacko, whenever the characters roll Initiative in the wilderness, ask that player if they'd like Jacko to assist them in the fight. If so, Jacko joins the fray alongside the party. After the fight, Jacko returns to this location unless the characters hire him again.

entries.name: Sword Ferns

entries: As you trudge through the mud, you tumble into a ravine of razor-sharp ferns. To continue, you must navigate this treacherous gully.

A character who examines the ferns can make a {@dc 12} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) check, identifying the plants as sword ferns—bladelike ferns endemic to jungles and wetlands—on a successful check.
To forge a path through the ferns, each character must succeed on one of the following checks:
{@b {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}).} The character hacks a path through the ferns with a weapon or stick.
{@b {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}).} The character finds a safe trail through the ferns used by wild animals.
On a failed check, the character takes {@damage 1d6} Slashing damage from the ferns on their way through the gully.

entries.name: Region 4: Tamarack Stand
entries: This hilly region's sparse trees have short, bristly needles. Forest fires and giant animals are more common in this stretch of the wilds.

entries.name: Tamarack Stand Features
entries: The tamarack stand has the following feature:

items.name: Lighting
items.entry: {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} illuminates the region.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:
Conifers rise from this highland's soft, peaty soil. Squirrels skitter about the fallen pinecones and pine needles that blanket the ground.

entries.name: Tamarack Stand Encounters
entries: Each time the characters explore this region, roll once on the Tamarack Stand Encounters table to determine what the characters encounter.

entries.name: Flash Fire

entries: Your expedition stops at the bottom of a steep gorge—a dead end. As you reorient yourselves, smoke begins to fill the air, and a sudden forest fire spreads through the dry canyon.
The conflagration roars in the party's direction, engulfing everything in its path.
To escape the fire unscathed, each character must succeed on one of the following ability checks:
{@b {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}).} The character scales the gorge to safety.
{@b {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}).} The character leaps across the branches, avoiding the flames below.
{@b {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}).} The character cuts through a thicket of trees with fire-resistant sap.
On a failed check, a character takes {@damage 2d6} Fire damage on their way to safety.

entries.name: Giant Spiders' Nest

entries: You wander into a maze of thick webs camouflaged between tall trees. Two massive arachnids descend on you with fangs bared.
Two {@creature Giant Spider|XMM|Giant Spiders} start combat, eager to make the characters their next meal.
Some characters begin this encounter trapped in the spiders' sticky web (see the "Giant Web" section). Roll a die for each character. On an odd number, the character starts their turn in the web.

entries.name: Giant Webs
entries: The giant spiders have woven a 20-foot {@variantrule Cube [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cube} of thick, sticky webs between the trees to snare prey. The webs are {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}, and the area within them is {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}.

The first time a creature enters the webs on a turn or starts its turn there, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until it breaks free or the webs are destroyed.
As an action, a creature {@condition Restrained|XPHB} by the webs can make a {@dc 12} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. If it succeeds, it is no longer Restrained.

The webs are flammable and laden with dry pollen and old animal carcasses. If the webs take Fire damage, the entire 20-foot Cube of webs ignites, and each creature Restrained by the webs takes {@damage 2d4} Fire damage. The webs then burn away and are destroyed at the end of the turn.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: After the fight, the characters find one magic item suspended in the webs; roll once on the {@area Magic Items|22e|x} table in {@adventure appendix A|HotB|4} (rerolling duplicates) to determine the item.

entries.name: Hobgoblin Patrol

entries: Ahead of you, three humanoid warriors in battered armor argue in harsh tones as they march through the forest. They haven't noticed you yet.

Three {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM|Hobgoblin Warriors} were recently separated from their squadron after a bitter defeat. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} hobgoblins are ornery and assault the characters on sight.

entries.name: Adjusting the Difficulty
entries: To make this encounter easier, you can reduce the number of {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM|Hobgoblin Warriors}. Conversely, add one more {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM} to increase the difficulty.

entries.name: Eavesdropping on the Hobgoblins
entries: To listen in on the hobgoblins' argument, a character must come within 30 feet of the patrol and make a {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the character hears the hobgoblins debating whether they should {@area ally with the bugbears|0bf|x} in the Caves of Chaos or hire the {@area ogre mercenary|08f|x} that dwells there (both are detailed in "{@adventure Caves of Chaos|HotB|1}"). On a failed check, the hobgoblins spot the eavesdropping character and start combat.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each hobgoblin carries a leather pouch that contains 4 GP.

entries.name: Pine Seeds

entries: Two types of trees grow in this area: one with russet bark and ruby-red pinecones, and another with gray bark and green pinecones. Squirrels and voles scamper about, collecting seeds from fallen cones. After so much travel, your stomachs growl with hunger.
The pine seeds from either tree are tasty, but the seeds from the ruby-red pinecones are poisonous.
A character can try to identify the edible pine seeds and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:
{@b {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}).} The character identifies both trees and which seeds are edible.
{@b {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}).} The character observes that local woodland critters eat pine seeds only from the green pinecones.
On a failed check, a character accidentally gathers the poisonous seeds.

entries.name: Poisonous Pine Seeds
entries: A creature that eats the seeds of a ruby-red pinecone must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until it finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Wilderness Encounters
entries: The following tables present additional random encounters the characters might face while exploring the wilderness. The tables are divided by wilderness region.
To generate a random encounter in a region, roll on the table for that region or choose an encounter you like. Use the map for that region to run combat encounters where necessary.

entries.caption: Random Fens Encounters
rows: Three {@creature Gnoll Warrior|XMM|Gnoll Warriors} scour the wetlands for treasure. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} gnolls demand one piece of equipment or a magic item from the characters and start combat if their demands aren't met.

Two {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM|Goblin Warriors} scoop mud from a lizardfolk mound as a belated birthday present for their boss. The goblins are {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} toward the characters and ask them to rate the gift.

A nearby bog burps out two {@creature Steam Mephit|XMM|Steam Mephits} that smell like rotten eggs. The {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} mephits try to amuse the characters with noisy emissions of stinky steam.
Two {@creature Kuo-Toa Marauder|HotB|Kuo-Toa Marauders} try to kidnap the characters and sacrifice them to an ancient swamp god.

A {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} {@creature Lizardfolk Warden|HotB} offers to guide the party through the fens. If the characters accept, the warden leads them to Jacko the spy (see the "{@area Spy's Campsite|210|x}" encounter).

Ahead, the corpse of a red-robed cultist lies face down in the mud. The corpse is a {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Zombie|XMM} that jolts up and ambushes any creature that comes within 5 feet of it.
Two {@creature Gray Ooze Glob|HotB|Gray Ooze Globs} hide beneath a rickety bridge, waiting to ambush the characters.
A sudden downpour causes a flash flood. Each character must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw to swim to dry land or take {@damage 2d8} Bludgeoning damage from the debris-infested torrent.

entries.caption: Random Tamarack Stand Encounters
rows: The characters meet Mallyn (see {@adventure appendix B|HotB|5|Mallyn}) on a daytime hike. She tells them that the pine seeds found throughout this region are delicious (see the "{@area Pine Seeds|226|x}" encounter).
A {@creature Stirge|XMM} feeds on an {@creature Ogre Zombie|XMM}. Both creatures are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward the characters.
The characters discover an abandoned wagon. One of the crates inside the wagon is a {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Mimic|XMM}.

A hiker ({@creature Commoner|XMM}) with a large backpack needs first aid. As a {@action Help|XPHB} action, a character can tend to the hiker and make a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the hiker pays the character 1 GP as thanks. On a failed check, the hiker scolds the party and asks them to leave.
A {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Ogre|XMM} rummages about an abandoned campsite for morsels.
A spooky tree marks the site of an occult graveyard. Four {@creature Skeleton|XMM|Skeletons} erupt from the unhallowed ground and ambush the characters.

{@creature Pral|HotB} and three {@creature Bandit|XMM|Bandits} sing merrily in a clearing. If Pral was defeated earlier (see the "{@area Bandit Ambush|1e0|x}" encounter), the bandit leader is his twin brother, Dral. If the characters have one or more musical instruments, the bandits are {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} and invite the characters to perform. Otherwise, the bandits are {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} and attempt to rob them.
A {@creature Red Dragon Wyrmling|XMM} soars overhead in the direction of the {@adventure Caves of Chaos|HotB|1}. It ignores the characters and is too far away for any interaction.

entries.caption: Random Trail Encounters
rows: Three {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM|Hobgoblin Warriors} accost the characters along the road.
Cornflower (see {@adventure appendix B|HotB|5|Cornflower}), the keep's {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} barn hand, invites the characters to a trailside picnic.
Four {@creature Bandit|XMM|Bandits} disguised as soldiers block the road, demanding a 10 GP toll. If the characters refuse or see through the disguises, the bandits fight.

An out-of-breath {@creature Guard|XMM} chases a runaway {@creature Bandit|XMM}. The {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} guard shouts for help in capturing the {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} criminal.

A proselytizing {@creature Cultist|XMM} tries to recruit the characters to the Cult of Chaos. The cultist is {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} but fights in self-defense in combat. If the characters accept, the cultist gives them each a small iron bell and performs a short initiation ceremony on the spot. Otherwise, the cultist curses them and continues on.
A {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} {@creature Knight|XMM} bound for the Keep on the Borderlands challenges the characters to a lighthearted—and nonlethal—duel.

Shannik (see {@adventure appendix B|HotB|5|Shannik}) leads a cavalry charge from the keep as part of a training exercise, and the characters are caught in its path. Each character must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 2d8} Bludgeoning damage from the charge.
A traveling {@creature Curate|HotB} offers to heal the characters' wounds if they have any.

entries.caption: Random Woods Encounters
rows: A {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM} suspended in a massive web calls for help. If freed, the {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} goblin helps the characters defeat two {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Giant Spider|XMM|Giant Spiders} that arrive moments later.

The characters come across a swath of trees rotted by a strange blight. A character who examines the trees can make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check; a successful check reveals the affliction stems from evil magic wrought by occult rituals.

Four {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} {@creature Commoner|XMM|Commoners} around a campsite invite the characters to camp with them for the evening; the characters can take a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} at this campsite.
Two {@creature Bugbear Warrior|XMM|Bugbear Warriors} use a rusty log saw to fell a mighty oak. The {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} lumberjacks fight any who disturb their work.
A {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} and ravenous {@creature Owlbear|XMM} searches for prey. It fights the characters on sight.
Oleira (see {@adventure appendix B|HotB|5|Oleira}) the trader is picking mushrooms. She can point the characters to Xanthe's hut (see the "{@area Hermit's Hut|1f2|x}" encounter).

A majestic stag appears in a picturesque clearing. If the characters approach the stag peacefully, it leads them to the sacred spring (see the "{@area Sacred Spring|1fb|x}" encounter). Otherwise, it flees.
The characters are caught in a lightning storm. Each character must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 2d8} Lightning damage.

data.name: Appendix B: NPCs
entries: This appendix includes all the NPCs that the players may encounter in the adventures. They are presented in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Andrella
entries: {@i Human Captain of the Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard Captain|XMM}

entries: This captain is strong, stern, and just.

items.name: Perfect Posture
items.entry: Andrella is as strict with her posture as she is with the law.

items.name: Role Model
items.entry: Many of the keep's young people admire Andrella and enjoy her goodhearted mentorship.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "A dastardly bandit, Pral, accosts travelers along the trail. Apparently he's quite handsome; I'm sure he'll look even better behind bars." (True})
{@i "The castellan tells me monsters are drawn to the Caves of Chaos in droves. I wonder why." (True})

entries.name: Bartho
entries: {@i Human Gate Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard|XMM}

entries: This gullible recruit spends more time dreaming than patrolling.

items.name: Distractable
items.entry: Bartho is easily distracted from his post because he'd rather be doing anything else.

items.name: Sleepy
items.entry: Bartho likes to catch a few winks during the night shift.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "If you can't afford a bed at the inn, Cornflower will let you sleep in the barn. The hay's real comfy." (True})
{@i "Minotaurs aren't real. They're just a myth told to scare little children from wandering into caves." (False})

entries.name: Cornflower
entries: {@i Halfling Barn Hand}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: This spunky stable hand isn't afraid to get her hands dirty.

items.name: Animal Lover
items.entry: Cornflower's best friends are all barn animals.

items.name: Idiomatic
items.entry: Cornflower likes to use animal idioms, such as "busy bee," "chicken out," and "hold your horses."

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Did you know animals have all sorts of special glands? Giant fire beetles are like big glowing cave lanterns! Isn't nature amazing?" (True})
{@i "Careful if you go trekking into the wilderness. The tamaracks are overrun with giant spiders." (True})

entries.name: Dwern
entries: {@i Dwarf Scribe}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: This gruff scribe prefers the company of books over people.

items.name: Bookworm
items.entry: Dwern has read more books than anyone else in the keep.

items.name: Curmudgeonly
items.entry: Dwern is ill-tempered toward younger people—which, to him, are most people.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The guild house's library boasts a modest but impressive collection of books on history and magic." (True})
{@i "There's an ancient statue somewhere in the forests north of the keep. It was once the site of strange rituals. Some say it still is." (True})

entries.name: Elandra
entries: {@i Elf Adviser}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: Elandra provides guidance to the castellan and citizens of the keep.

items.name: Cautious
items.entry: When presented with a choice, Elandra typically prefers the option with the least amount of risk.

items.name: Complainer
items.entry: Nothing is ever good enough for Elandra.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Every night, the tavern hosts a rowdy little drinking game with prizes. It's not for me." (True})
{@i "Kalista, the keep's blacksmith, doesn't sell weapons to adventurers. If you want to know why, ask her." (True})

entries.name: Fazzir
entries: {@i Human Priest}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Curate|HotB}

entries: This spiritual leader offers counsel and healing to all who seek the temple.

items.name: Altruistic
items.entry: Fazzir puts the needs of others before his own.

items.name: Trusting
items.entry: Fazzir always assumes the best of people.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The keep's former priest, Ivlis, left a large collection of books on all matter of subjects—even occult rituals." (True})
{@i "Anyone entering the inner bailey is bound to cross paths with Shannik, sergeant of the guard. I think he's a little too hard on new recruits." (True})

entries.name: Gala
entries: {@i Human Gate Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard|XMM}

entries: Though she's memorized all the keep's laws, this guard still has much to learn.

items.name: By the Books
items.entry: Gala clings to the keep's laws—and often recites them aloud—whenever she must make a decision.

items.name: Naive
items.entry: Gala believes that life is fair, people mostly tell the truth, and good always prevails.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "I've heard the captain of the guard, Andrella, plans to retire soon." (False})
{@i "The keep's coat of arms honors its cavalry, thirty riders strong. I hope to become one." (True})

entries.name: Haldryck
entries: {@i Dwarf Innkeeper}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: Jovial and accommodating, Haldryck is a fast friend to anyone who visits his inn.

items.name: Epicurean
items.entry: Good food and drink are the keys to Haldryck's heart.

items.name: Overseller
items.entry: Haldryck advertises his inn's basic necessities—like clean sheets and doors with locks—as luxury amenities.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The food at the tavern is the best in the Borderlands!" (Doubtful})
{@i "My inn is the only place visitors to the keep can stay overnight." (False})

entries.name: Kalista
entries: {@i Dwarf Blacksmith}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: The keep's taciturn, hardworking smith prefers to let her hammer do the talking.

items.name: Standoffish
items.entry: Kalista is curt toward people she doesn't know, especially adventurers.

items.name: Stern
items.entry: Kalista never cracks a smile.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Every now and then, adventurers return from the Caves of Chaos with magic weapons, but most of the time they don't come back at all." (True})
{@i "Mind your equipment around oozes. Their touch can corrode even the sturdiest of metals." (True})

entries.name: Lenk
entries: {@i Human Jeweler}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: This elderly jeweler can identify and appraise any gemstone.

items.name: Faultfinder
items.entry: Lenk has a knack for spotting flaws, be they in things or people.

items.name: Pessimistic
items.entry: Lenk always sees the worst part of any situation.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Your money isn't safe at the bank. I hear a burglar broke in recently and stole every last coin." (Partially true; the burglar was unsuccessful})
{@i "Some stones hide things. The next time you're in an ancient dungeon or old cave, inspect the walls closely. You just might find a secret door." (True})

entries.name: Mallyn
entries: {@i Human Traveler}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: This young wayfarer's heart is filled with wanderlust.

items.name: Easy Come, Easy Go
items.entry: Mallyn doesn't get attached to possessions or acquaintances.

items.name: Inquisitive
items.entry: Mallyn eagerly asks strangers lots of questions.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Don't wander into the fens unless you're looking for trouble. The lizardfolk there don't like visitors." (True})
{@i "My uncle Umbrusk runs the tavern in the keep. He hears all kinds of gossip in the taproom." (True})

entries.name: Oleira
entries: {@i Human Shopkeeper}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: This merchant and mother of two deals in wares ranging from common trade goods to curious bric-a-brac.

items.name: Fastidious
items.entry: Oleira can't stand dusty wares. Every item must be spotless.

items.name: Parental
items.entry: Oleira sometimes treats her customers like she does her children.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "A hermit, Xanthe, was cast out of the keep for practicing evil magic. I hear she was in a cult. Think of the children!" (False})
{@i "The keep's two outer gate guards, Bartho and Gala, are both so green. I'm not sure which of them I trust less to protect us." (True})

entries.name: Quink
entries: {@i Halfling Banker}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: Quink is a miserly moneylender.

items.name: Frugal
items.entry: Quink never budges on matters of money.

items.name: Garrulous
items.entry: Conversations with Quink last twice as long as they should.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Good supplies are a sound investment. Ruckus at the provisioner's shop can outfit you with quality gear." (True})
{@i "I've heard dragons are a bit like bankers—we obsess over every coin. If you ever encounter a dragon, don't touch its hoard unless you want to meet its wrath." (True})

entries.name: Ruckus
entries: {@i Halfling Shopkeeper}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: The owner of the provisioner's shop is small but has a big personality.

items.name: Loud
items.entry: Ruckus compensates for his short stature by shouting up to taller customers.

items.name: Everything Has a Place
items.entry: Despite the mess in his shop, Ruckus always knows exactly where to find just what he's looking for.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "I hear goblins throw wild parties." (Oh Yeah}!)
{@i "Lenk the jeweler gives a fair price for gems and precious stones. He lives in the private apartments." (True})

entries.name: Shannik
entries: {@i Human Sergeant of the Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard Captain|XMM}

entries: Captain Andrella's second in command brooks no evildoers.

items.name: Brusque
items.entry: When Shannik can substitute a reply with a grunt, he does so.

items.name: Shortsighted
items.entry: Shannik's plans and actions fail to account for long-term repercussions.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "An adventurer is only as good as their gear. Oleira at the trader's shop is a friend of mine. She can sell you armor and weapons." (True})
{@i "A real soldier can sleep off any injury. After a battle, I usually rent a bed at the inn. I always sleep better there." (True})

entries.name: Toryn
entries: {@i Human Guild Master}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Noble|XMM}

entries: This guild master helps fellow artisans get a good deal for their wares and services.

items.name: Judgmental
items.entry: Toryn looks down on artisans who refuse to join the guild.

items.name: Witty
items.entry: Toryn says smart things and always has the last word.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "Castellan Winvarle is the ultimate authority in the keep." (True})
{@i "The Borderlands are home to all sorts of trades: musicians, mercenaries, treasure-seekers, spies—even monsters can have a profession. My advice? Pay them what they ask." (True})

entries.name: Umbrusk
entries: {@i Human Barkeep}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: Umbrusk serves up drinks, food, and gossip at the keep's tavern.

items.name: Eavesdropper
items.entry: Umbrusk listens to his patrons' conversations.

items.name: Good Memory
items.entry: Umbrusk never forgets a face or name.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "A traveler named Mallyn walks the trails outside the keep. If you meet her, say hello for me! She's my niece." (True})
{@i "Whenever I order a cake, it gets seized by goblins, roadside bandits—you name it. I guess everybody likes dessert." (True})

entries.name: Winvarle
entries: {@i Human Castellan}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Knight|XMM}

entries: The keep's noble commander leads his soldiers whenever the keep comes under attack.

items.name: Idealistic
items.entry: Winvarle's ideals are rooted in lofty notions of righteousness.

items.name: Oblivious
items.entry: While he excels at battle strategy, Winvarle scarcely knows the inner workings of his own keep.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "The Cult of Chaos is an affront to all that is good." (True})
{@i "Anyone can pledge to defend the keep. Talk to Andrella in the inner gatehouse if you'd like to join the keep's defenders." (True})

entries.name: Xanthe
entries: {@i Elf Hermit}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Commoner|XMM}

entries: One of the Borderlands' oldest and wisest residents was banished from the keep for crimes she didn't commit.

items.name: Bad Reputation
items.entry: Xanthe was wrongfully exiled for using occult magic.

items.name: Distrustful
items.entry: Xanthe doesn't trust strangers.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "A spy named Jacko prowls the fens. Be wary if you meet him. He'll do anything for coin—even kill." (True})
{@i "The temple's head priest is a demon worshiper." (Partially true; Xanthe is referring to Ivlis, the former priest})

entries.name: Yvette
entries: {@i Human Bank Guard}

items.name: Statblock:
items.entry: {@creature Guard|XMM}

entries: This corrupt guard exploits her station for selfish ends.

items.name: Bitter
items.entry: Yvette thinks the world owes her.

items.name: Grifter
items.entry: Yvette is always hunting for new ways to get rich quick.

entries.name: Rumors
items: {@i "There's an alms box at the temple that usually contains a few gold pieces. I hear Fazzir doesn't even lock it." (True})
{@i "If you find yourself face to face with an owlbear, just play dead. It will quickly get bored and move on." (False})
